DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE ERIC LAIDLAW ROBINSON, M.P.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I have to inform the Senate of the death of the Honourable Eric Robinson, M.P. I am sure that all honourable senators were shocked and saddened to learn of his untimely death. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 7 January 1981 of the Honourable Eric Laidlaw Robinson, a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of McPherson from 1972 and a Minister of the Crown from 1975 to 1980; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service; and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

Eric Robinson was born in Brisbane on 18 January 1929. He was educated at the Church of England Grammar School in Brisbane and later at the Slade School in Warwick. After leaving school he enjoyed a very successful career with his family's sporting goods business where he displayed the qualities which were later to equip him so well for public office. In the political arena Eric Robinson made a great contribution to his party, his State and the nation. Prior to entering Parliament he was President of the Queensland division of the Liberal Party from 1968 to 1973. This was a period of great change and development for the Party in Queensland. Eric Robinson worked untiringly in the interests of the Liberal Party. His efforts in Queensland, particularly at the organisational level, will not be forgotten. No one could doubt the strength and courage of his convictions.

Eric Robinson was elected to Parliament for the Division of McPherson in 1972; he was re-elected on four subsequent occasions. His considerable abilities were recognised early in his parliamentary career and he contributed significantly to the successful functioning of the Opposition during the period 1972 to 1975. Upon entering government in 1975 Eric Robinson became Minister for the Capital Territory. From 1976 to 1977 he was Minister for Post and Telecommunications and Minister Assisting the Treasurer. He was Minister for Finance from 1977 to 1980.

Eric Robinson administered each of his portfolios with energy, commitment and concern. Whilst he was always a fearless advocate of the policies and proposals he considered to be right, he was always willing to consider the other person's viewpoint. He possessed great natural charm and dignity. He was a man of the highest personal and political integrity. As such he won the warm respect of members on both sides of the Parliament. The loss of Eric Robinson, a man in the prime of his life and with much still to contribute to the life of his nation, is indeed a tragedy. To his widow, Narelle, and the other members of his family we offer our deepest sympathy in the loss they have sustained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition joins with Senator Carrick and the Government in paying tribute to the late Eric Robinson. His career, both in business and later in Liberal Party politics, showed him to be a man of considerable drive, energy and dedication. It is interesting to record that in 1963 he is said to have invited 18 friends to his home to form the Surfers Paradise branch of the Liberal Party and that he left that branch as the largest Liberal Party branch in Australia. I make that observation simply because he was throughout his political career very much a party man. In Federal politics he was instrumental, it is said, in the rise of both Mr McMahon, as he then was, and Mr Fraser to Liberal Party leadership. After being Minister for the Capital Territory he was promoted to the position of Minister for Post and Telecommunications and then more recently to Minister for Finance.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst those of us on this side of the Senate were not always sympathetic with the general political outlook of the late Eric Robinson, we were all able to recognise that he was a man who had the courage of his convictions and a great independence of mind. The findings of the McGregor royal commission stand as testimony to his integrity. Amongst his ministerial achievements for which he will be remembered are the setting up of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as an independent body to preside over the broadcasting industry in Australia, his dedication to the notion of taking broadcasting out of politics and his belief that the public interest was best served by having a system of regulation of the ownership of broadcasting stations. He will also be remembered as a Minister for his support to this chamber's first Aboriginal member. That support, which I understand was significant, was not only successful but also characteristically courageous. Such a man will be missed by his friends, who deeply respected him as a man of courage, integrity and personal charm. The Opposition extends its sympathy to his widow and family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to express personally and on behalf of the National Country Party regret and sympathy at the death of the Honourable Eric Laidlaw Robinson. Mr Robinson was a relatively young man and I have no shadow of doubt that he had a great contribution still to make to his own colleagues and, indeed, to Australians generally. It is a shame that such a man's period on this planet should be cut so short. Mr Robinson was indeed an accomplished member of the community in which he lived. He was a man of very great conviction and dedication to those things in which he believed so strongly. His dedication and conviction were evidenced in the part he played in both the organisational and parliamentary areas of politics. Once again, I can only offer my personal sympathy and my party's sympathy to Mr Robinson's widow and his family in their great loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate my party and myself with this condolence motion. For over 20 years I was very proud to call Eric Robinson and his delightful wife Narelle my close personal friends. I always found Eric Robinson to be an extremely honest man, honest to the point of bluntness. Quite often, his frankness would lose him contact with people, but he was a man who believed that to be totally honest at all times was the main criterion.

SPEECH.PARA: Politically, he and I were always as wide apart as two persons could be. Even within the framework of the Liberal Party, when I was a member of that party, we would differ philosophically on almost all issues; but that never at any time hindered the very deep and lasting friendship that the two of us formed. During his lifetime I was incredibly impressed with his sense of service. We know that he was a very successful businessman. Quite often he ridiculed the low remuneration of members of parliament and Ministers of the Crown in particular-a view with which I heartily concur. He was a great campaigner for justice to be done in this area, not because of his own position-we know that he was a relatively wealthy man-but because he saw as absurd the fact that he had to pay the managers whom he had to appoint to his private business in order to keep it going more than he was receiving as a Minister of the Crown. He pointed out that absurdity time and time again.

Eric Robinson was a man who was capable of many voluntary and involuntary kindnesses to both friend and foe alike. Typical is the time when I was not included in the Fraser Ministry when the Fraser Government was returned in 1975. One of the first people to knock on my door and enter my office to extend his sympathy was Eric Robinson. He was a man of great compassion, a man of courage and a very kind and gentle man. I also want to put on record my deep sympathy for his wonderful wife Narelle and his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my Queensland colleagues and myself I join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and those who have spoken to this condolence motion for the late Eric Robinson. I will be eternally grateful for the friendship that was extended to me by Eric Robinson and his sweet and loving wife Narelle. Eric Robinson was a man of high integrity. He was honest and sincere in everything he undertook. He became the President of the Liberal Party in Queensland in 1968, when it was going through a rather traumatic experience. It was the dedication, sincerity and hard work of Eric Robinson that brought the members of the Liberal Party together and welded them into a very strong and viable force. It was in 1963, after the State election, that he formed the first branch of the Liberal Party on the Gold Coast. He was elected to Federal Parliament in 1972 because of his hard work and dedication not only to the Liberal Party but also to all people in Queensland. I believe that the Liberal Party in Queensland owes a great debt of gratitude to the hard work, the sincerity and the courage of the late Eric Robinson. There are those who will say that he was elected on Democratic Labor Party preferences, but the DLP supported him because that Party and its members had such a high regard for his honesty and his integrity.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I want to clear up a point here today. It has been reported a number of times since Eric Robinson's death that I beat him for preselection to fill the casual Senate vacancy in 1972. That is not true because Eric Robinson did not nominate for preselection. Therefore, what has been reported in the Press is quite inaccurate. I well recall, Mr President, the night of that preselection when I won endorsement by the Liberal Party. With my wife, my daughter, and my son and his wife, I was taken into the office of the General Secretary of the Queensland division of the Liberal Party, Mr Keith Livingstone. Mr Eric Robinson spoke to us and congratulated me. Whatever Eric Robinson endeavoured to do he did well. After congratulating me and talking to me for a short time, he said: 'Neville, we in the Liberal Party are proud to have you as our endorsed candidate to fill this casual vacancy. But let me give you one little piece of advice. Neville, it must be done well'. That was Eric Robinson. Anything he undertook to do he did well, to the best of his ability. He put everything he had into it and he was ably supported by a sweet and loving wife, Narelle.

As I said earlier, Mr President, I shall be eternally grateful for his friendship and for the encouragement that he gave me on many occasions, as he did so many people in my State of Queensland, not only in the Liberal Party but also outside the Party-people he got to know and people he worked with and became friends with. He was the kind of man to whom one could go at any time of the day or night for counselling or for guidance; he would willingly give that. The day when Eric Robinson was called home by our loving God was a sad one not only for the Liberal Party in Queensland but also for the people of Queensland and, I believe, for the people of this nation. He contributed much in his lifetime and he had much more to contribute. Mr President, each day you say the Lord's Prayer. You say: 'Thy will be done'. That was the case when He called Eric Robinson home to glory. On my own behalf and on behalf of my Queensland colleagues, I extend our deepest sympathies to Eric's wife and family. Let me say finally, sir, that I was proud to know him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in the savagery of Australian politics much was said of Eric Robinson which was unfair and much was done to him which he did not deserve. It is a great pity that he is not able to hear the many things that are being said of him now-those things which he truly deserved. He is not able to spurn-I doubt that he would do so-those who now see him in a far better light. Eric Robinson was a man of compassion, and I experienced that compassion some 12 months ago when I was ill. He was one of the first to brush aside the barriers which kept visitors away and he came to offer me his assistance. I regret that his illness was so complete and so finite that I was not able to respond. Although he was diametrically opposed to me politically and philosophically, I came to know him and to be friendly with him. He did not need to do the things that he did. For instance, he did not need to come to my assistance when I was under pressure in Queensland in regard to the civil liberties campaign, but he did so. For that reason I extend my words of sympathy to his widow and to his family. I knew the father well and I came to know the son well; they were in the same mould.

The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Racist Stereotypes in Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that whereas advertising featuring racist stereotypes is offensive to many Australian citizens and
that whereas it may contribute to the development of racist attitudes in certain individuals,
and noting that a recent Kelvinator air-conditioner advertisement featuring Dick Emery as dominant white colonialist and as obsequious Asian servant is of the type referred to above,
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the members in Parliament assembled will act to preserve the human rights and dignity of all Australians by:
(a) Calling for the withdrawal of the Kelvinator/Dick Emery advertisement, and
(b) Passing legislation which places a ban, with appropriate penalties, on the use of racist stereotypes in advertising,
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance Contributions: Tax Deductibility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate and the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth.

That due to higher medical and hospital insurances, the voluntary health insurances contributors are finding that their weekly buying power is greatly reduced. The contributors are actually subsidising the non-contributors. The contributors are greatly disadvantaged by the present taxation system. We therefore call upon the Commonwealth Government to make the health insurance contributions tax deductible.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate and House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will take immediate steps to bring about the wishes expressed in our petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Rights Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Whereas before Europeans settled in Australia, the Aboriginal peoples of Australia had lived on their traditional lands from time immemorial and had in Aboriginal law and customs a clear title to those lands; and

whereas Europeans and other non-Aboriginal people have occupied and used most of the traditional lands of the Aboriginal peoples against their will and without negotiation, compensation or treaty, and
whereas it has been the practice of nations established in territories previously occupied by indigenous inhabitants to reach a negotiated settlement with those inhabitants, and

whereas that occupation has seriously damaged the traditional way of life of Aboriginal Australians and has caused poverty and hardship to be the fate of the great majority of their surviving descendants, and

whereas the surviving descendants of the Aboriginal peoples have expressed a wish to have their rights to land acknowledged, to preserve their link with their Aboriginal ancestors and to maintain their distinctive identity with its own cultural heritage, and
whereas the people of Australia in 1967 voted overwhelmingly that the Commonwealth Parliament should have responsibility for laws relating to Aboriginal Australians, and

whereas it is accepted internationally by the United Nations organisation, that each country should work to establish the rights of indigenous peoples to self-determination, non-discrimination and the enjoyment of their own culture, and
whereas the Woodward Commission in 1974 established principles by which Aboriginal rights to land should be acknowledged and realised, and

whereas the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament in February 1975 resolved that Aboriginal Australians should be compensated for the loss of their traditional lands and for the damage to their way of life, and
whereas the National Aboriginal Conference unanimously resolved in April 1979 in Canberra to ask the Commonwealth Government to negotiate a Treaty with Aboriginal Australians.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government should invite the Aboriginal people of Australia to negotiate a Treaty with the Commonwealth of Australia, and any Treaty should contain provisions relating to the following matters: (i) The protection of Aboriginal identity, languages, law and culture, (ii) The recognition and restoration of rights to land by applying, throughout Australia, the recommendations of the Woodward Commission, (iii) The conditions governing mining and exploitation of other natural resources on Aboriginal land, (iv) Compensation to Aboriginal Australians for the loss of traditional lands and for damage to those lands and to their traditional way of life, (v) The right of Aboriginal Australians to control their own affairs and to establish their own associations for this purpose.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Patients' Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume, Chaney and Jessop.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that allegations have been made by litigants that unjust decisions in relation to ancillary matters are being made at the Family Court of Australia.

We call on the Government to amend Section 79 (1) of the Family Law Act, to allow all Family Courts to be open and publication of details of proceedings permitted, provided names of parties and other identifying information is prohibited from disclosure.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Chipp and Senator Ryan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to a question which I asked of him on 28 April 1980 about the multiplier effect on employment of new mining projects. On that day the Minister undertook to provide me with estimates and projections made by the Department concerning 'the employment of families, the creation of societies and neighbourhoods and the multiplier effect'. I refer the Minister to the fact that since that date on several occasions I have sought information regarding this matter. So far I have been provided only with a list of projects, their projected costs and direct employment impact. I again ask the Minister whether he is able to supply the Senate with the projections, some of which he claims to have seen personally, relating to 'the employment of families, the creation of societies and neighbourhoods and the multiplier effect'.

—I regret it if we have not provided information on that aspect of the question to which Senator Button referred. It was my intention that the full details be given. I will certainly take up the matter and see whether I can get him the remaining information in the very near future.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy to a report that Japan plans to buy coal from western parts of the United States of America for the first time and may invest in United States railroads and ports to expedite shipment of this steam coal. The report also states that Japan is seeking an alternative source of steam coal which it now gets mainly from Australia. I preface my question by saying that this report alarms me as I live in the West Moreton district, which is in and around Ipswich, where coal of this nature is readily available. Is the Minister aware of this move by the Japanese? If so, is such a move a result of the growing industrial unrest and strikes in this industry?

—I was recently in Japan with the Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee. During that time a frequent question asked of me and, I have no doubt, of other Ministers with some anxiety by the Japanese was the question of industrial unrest in Australia and the continuity of supplies. I was able to inform the Japanese with reasonable confidence that in the past our track record had been pretty good in world terms but that in recent times we had had some aberrations.
—Around election times usually.

—Not around election times. The time of greatest industrial strife in Australia was when a present member of the Australian Labor Party in another place was both the Federal President of the ALP and the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and a Labor government was in power. The conjunction of all those skills produced the worst industrial strife in Australia. Nevertheless, it is vital that coal and other energy products be provided to the world markets. It is vital that there be continuity of supply. There is no doubt that any protracted industrial unrest will make the preparation of contracts difficult. It is a worrying thing. I believe that a major problem for Australia in the years immediately ahead will be to find a practical and permanent solution to the causes of industrial unrest.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to his recent statements that in fact there have been changes to the procedures and guidelines governing the consideration by Commonwealth medical officers of applications for invalid pensions. I ask the Minister: Can he allow the Senate, the Parliament and therefore the people involved to know what these changes to the guidelines are? If not, why not?

—I am not aware of any recent statement about changes in guidelines with respect to the invalid pension. I do recollect saying that there have been some changes in the procedures in the Department of Health for ensuring that there is uniform medical assessment. But if the honourable senator likes to draw my attention to specific statements about which he is concerned I will endeavour to respond to him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question merely because I did ask the Minister-Hansard will confirm this-about a statement he made that there had been changes to the procedures for Commonwealth medical officers dealing with applications for invalid pensions, and I repeat the question. Can we have details of what those changes are? If not, why not?

—As I indicated in my answer to the question, all that has happened is that there has been an attempt by the Department of Health to ensure greater uniformity of medical assessment. I will examine the question in the Hansard, as the honourable senator suggests I should-I hope he will not correct his question-and I will then see whether any further reply is required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I draw the Minister's attention to a letter, a copy of which I have supplied to the Minister, which appeared in the Australian of 9 February 1981 and related to the invalid pension paid to handicapped people living in State institutions. I ask the Minister to comment on the letter and in particular the following claim:

QUESTION.PARA: Since the 1 January, 1981, any handicapped person of pensionable age admitted to an institution run by the State will receive the princely sum of $17.80 a fortnight to buy clothes, personal effects, toiletries, to spend on any outings and to save for long range events such as holidays.

Will the Minister inform the Senate why the pension received by such handicapped residents has been reduced from $44.80 to $17.80 a fortnight when at the same time the amount for maintenance going to the State has been increased from $93.40 to $120.40 a fortnight? Will he also inform the Senate what improvements in board might be effected as a result of the increased maintenance being paid to the State institutions? Does the Minister agree that the main goal of these institutions should be the rehabilitation of its handicapped residents into community living? Does the Minister also agree that in this the International Year of Disabled Persons the Government must take the lead if it is to achieve an enlightened attitude by the public towards handicapped people? If so, will he assure the Senate that consideration will be given to removing this Commonwealth-State arrangement which makes the rehabilitation of handicapped people living in State institutions even more difficult?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator did provide me with a copy of the letter which appeared in the Australian but I had in fact seen it when it was published on 9 February. The matters raised in the letter in fact relate to charges which are made in State institutions in Queensland and relate to the net income which is available to invalid pensioners after they meet those charges. I think many honourable senators would be aware that the level of those charges is determined by the State and does not come within the Social Security portfolio. On the other hand, the social security legislation which applies to benevolent institutions does provide that where a pensioner is living in an approved benevolent home an amount equal to 87 1/2 per cent of the pension should be paid directly to the home in respect of his care and accommodation. In fact there are no benevolent homes in Queensland which are caught by that legislation but the State Government has tied the charges made in State nursing homes to the level specified for benevolent homes under the Commonwealth legislation. In fact, it is Commonwealth policy to achieve as great a uniformity as possible in the charges levied in respect of long term nursing home patients.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst the matter of these charges referred to in the letter and referred to by Senator Missen in his question is a matter for the State, it is a fact that there is no uniformity of charging among benevolent homes, non-government nursing homes, public hospitals and most State nursing homes. The point which I think is the central point of Senator Missen's question is whether the charges and the amount which is left for the people concerned are in line with their need for rehabilitation. That is a particular point to which I have not given consideration. It may be that different considerations ought to apply in the circumstances of those institutions. In the case where full board and lodgings are in effect being provided in other forms of institutions, perhaps for the very old people who are in them, it may well be quite appropriate. Perhaps for others it is not. I will examine that aspect of the honourable senator's question and see whether I should add to that reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Will the Australian Government, through its National Parks and Wildlife Service, prevail upon the Northern Territory Government not to interpret the rather inconclusive findings of Coroner Barritt in the Azaria Chamberlain inquest as an open invitation to embark upon a wholesale campaign of carnage of Northern Territory fauna?

—I commence by saying on behalf of all honourable senators that the whole Azaria Chamberlain case was a very unfortunate one. It was a tragedy for the family. I think the coroner raised some very important issues in his findings. It has already been said that people who go into national parks in an attempt to get close to nature must inevitably be prepared to take some risks in terms of the relationship they will have with certain kinds of wildlife.
—But we have run out of kids to feed them.

—I want to respond to Senator Cavanagh's interjection to make sure that it goes into Hansard by saying that really it was not a terribly appropriate kind of interjection to make. Consultations are going on at present between the officers of various departments of the Northern Territory Government in the light of the coroner's comments. I think the Northern Territory Government is quite sensitive to the points which are raised by the honourable senator and I would not want to overreact to anything it does. But it is essentially a matter for the Northern Territory Government and for its administration.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer when the Parliament can expect to be presented with the legislation promised in the Prime Minister's policy speech to provide further taxation concessions for investment in the Australian film industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the legislation is in hand and I expect that some early introduction of it could be made. I think the Treasurer made some statements with regard to it and it is anticipated that the legislation will be brought forward in this session. The statement of the Treasurer on 18 December and one by the then Minister for Home Affairs gave some details of it. It is proposed that the provisions of the concession be retrospective to 1 October 1980. But, as I said, it is hoped that the legislation will be brought in shortly.

—I ask Senator Carrick a question in his dual capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for National Development and Energy. I am sure the Minister will have noted from Press reports or cleverly placed leaks the recent attempt by the Minister for Trade and Resources to concentrate within his Department all effective responsibility for the implementation of Australia's uranium policy. Has such a submission been considered by Cabinet? Will the Minister give a firm assurance to the Senate that he and the Prime Minister will be resisting this move so that it cannot be a catastrophic end to our so-called nuclear safeguards policy?

—Senator Chipp, of course, would know that I would not comment on anything that may or may not have happened inside Cabinet. But I am able to say that if he were to peruse the Administrative Arrangements Orders, which are those that govern the portfolio responsibilities of the various Ministers of the Ministry and Cabinet, he would find that the responsibility for uranium is divided among some three or four Ministers. I have very significant responsibilities, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade and Resources certainly have. No alteration has been made to the Administrative Arrangements Orders. I am unaware of any changes that might be contemplated. An announcement will be made should any changes be made. I will refer Senator Chipp's question to the Prime Minister as Administrative Arrangements Orders are his concern.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. It relates to one of the paramount political issues for this nation and for South Australia in particular; namely, the urgent need to improve the quality of water in the River Murray, to establish a permanent program to reduce and control salinity levels especially for Riverland and other Murray lands irrigation, for Whyalla and other country areas supplied by pipeline from the river and, not least, for the regular water supply of Adelaide. What initiative has the Commonwealth taken to confer with State governments toward vesting the River Murray Commission with the necessary and permanent powers to establish and maintain good standards of water quality throughout the whole of the Murray, Murrumbidgee and Darling basins? In particular, what were the achievements of the meeting between the Minister and State Ministers for water resources which he arranged this month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's question is very important. It relates to three States. It is most important for South Australia, which is on the end of the line. It has concerns not only about quantity but also of course about the grave problem of salinity. That matter is one of my direct ministerial responsibilities, both in the Australian Water Resources Council area and, primarily, as it relates to the River Murray Commission.
—Tell us what you are going to do about it.

—I will be happy to tell Senator Primmer and others what we will do about it. We have provided considerable assistance for salinity control works to the three States since 1978-79. This year a total of $4.5m is being made available on a dollar for dollar basis to each of the three States for urgent works recommended in the Maunsell report's plan to deal with salinity and drainage problems in the Murray Valley. In addition, two amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act which were made last year to liberalise income tax concessions to land owners in respect of expenditure on water conservation and conveyance and salinity control and drainage should provide an invaluable financial incentive to landowners to deal with salinity problems at their source. The Government also strongly supports the completion of a new River Murray Waters Agreement, mainly to give the River Murray Commission water quality responsibilities in its operations and investigations. The draft new agreement currently under examination includes provisions for the Commission to make recommendations to the States on water quality objectives and, where appropriate, standards for various locations on the river.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Teague will be aware, on 12 February I convened a meeting of State Ministers responsible for water conservation matters. At the meeting progress towards a new River Murray Waters Agreement was particularly good. A few issues still remain unresolved. They have been taken back by State Ministers to their respective governments. I very much hope that it will be possible to produce a new agreement without much longer delay and that there will be matching Commonwealth and State legislation. I should emphasise that the issue of licences on tributaries of the Murray, except those above Albury, is the sole responsibility of State governments. The Commonwealth has no intention of interfering or exerting pressure in this matter. Rather, our main concern is to accelerate the completion of a new River Murray Waters Agreement which will give the River Murray Commission some water quality responsiblities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs or the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I refer to the draft Industries Assistance Commission report which, as the Minister knows, concerns the future of the Australian car manufacturing industry. The report has somewhat stunned Australian car manufacturers, particularly those in South Australia, because very drastic proposals which have been put forward to the Government for consideration arise from that report. The employers and the unions in the industry are most concerned about it. I ask the Minister: What consideration has been given to the report so far? What procedures will be adopted arising from the draft report? Will there be discussions with the industry before that draft report is finally settled? Does the Minister intend to make a quick response to this report which, as I pointed out, proposes very radical changes in the industry to ensure that manufacturers, particularly in my State of South Australia, are reassured that investment and development policies will not be disturbed as proposed in the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, as well as all South Australians, will be fully aware of the importance to the State of South Australia of the matter which he has raised. I believe that is fully appreciated. The report that Senator Bishop refers to is one, of course, that has been contemplated by the industry for some time. It has been known that the Industries Assistance Commission has been undertaking a study of this kind for some years now. It is expected that any decision which the Government might take in respect of the report when it is finally handed down would affect the motor vehicle industry after 1985. Consequently, it is not as though the report will have an immediate impact on the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The report that Senator Bishop is talking about is a draft from the IAC. It will be subject to further hearings by the IAC, at which time both the South Australian Government and the manufacturers will have an opportunity to put forward their views. Consequently, the matter will be open for some time yet before the IAC delivers its report directly to the Government. It will be at that point that the Government will be considering the matter which, no doubt, will be some time next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs see the article in the Australian on Monday, 23 February, relating to the setting up of an Aboriginal school in Brisbane? Is the story true? Did the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs prepare a scheme for the establishment in Brisbane of a school solely for Aboriginal children? What consultation occurred between the Commonwealth and State authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article in the Australian of 23 February to which the honourable senator referred. The proposal which he referred to was the result of a workshop staged by the Aboriginal and Island Catholic Council on 22 and 23 January. The workshop was an initiative of the black community and was sponsored at community request by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The workshop concentrated on suggestions and proposals for alternative schooling methods to deal with special problems facing inner city Aboriginal children, the children who do not attend school and who are constantly in trouble as a result of anti-social behaviour. As a result of that workshop, a steering committee has been set up to consider, as one option, the possibility of establishing a learning centre to provide for those children a desirable alternative to truancy and to attempt to help them reach a stage where they can join the mainstream of state education.

ANSWER.PARA: The workshop was attended by representatives of the State and Commonwealth education departments, the Catholic Education Office, the University of Queensland, the Department of Social Security, the Office of Child Care, the National Aboriginal Education Committee and by other government and non-government bodies and individuals seeking to pool their knowledge and ideas. However, at this stage no firm proposal has been advanced. There is no indication that, if an additional educational facility of this type were to be provided for children with particular social and educational disadvantages, it would be limited to black children. My Department's role in this matter has been that of facilitator to enable interested groups to meet and discuss a social problem of mutual concern.

I finish by saying that if there are children who are not coping with the normal education system and for whom truancy is a way of life, if people want to suggest what might be appropriate alternative means of helping them and if those suggestions come from a meeting of Aboriginal people, they should not be rejected out of hand for that reason alone.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and concerns the provision of essential services on Aboriginal communities. One of the senior men from Ngurrkurr rang me to say:

QUESTION.PARA: Ngurrkurr is the biggest rubbish dump in Arnhem Land.

He explained that insufficient funds had been made available to the council to carry out essential services. I know that the Minister will be as concerned as I am about the situation. I ask: What action can he take to see that municipal services are provided on Aboriginal communities?

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some problems in this matter. The responsibility for essential services was transferred to the Northern Territory Government in July 1978.
—A mistake. You should never have done it.

—Well, the responsibility was transferred specifically to the Northern Territory Government in July 1978. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs continued to act as agent for the Northern Territory Government until last year. The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has stated publicly several times that over $14m has been allocated this year for essential services in Aboriginal communities. I am sure that the honourable senator who asked the question would have seen some of the statements.
—I have not seen the result of anything.

—This allocation is said to have covered water and electricity services, sewerage, roads and airstrips. No doubt the Chief Minister would be the person to provide the honourable senator with details of particular programs within that allocation for essential services expenditure. We have not been able to get the details, and I am afraid it is a matter to which he has to turn to the Northern Territory if he wants an answer.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. What responsibilities does the Minister see his Department as having in making sure that the communities have these essential services?

—My Department is keen to provide advisory services and to act as broker where it can for any communities in need of services, but my Department does not have funding responsibility; these funds are Northern Territory funds.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware that some overseas airlines are seeking to use Adelaide Airport on an international basis? Can the Minister say whether facilities, particularly runways, at Adelaide Airport will be upgraded to accommodate planes such as DC10s and Boeing 747s? If it is intended to upgrade Adelaide Airport can the Minister say when this will be done?

—All honourable senators will appreciate Senator Young's particular interest in this matter. I know he has been following it through with great vigour. I have no particular information on whether 747s or DC10s will be allowed to land at Adelaide Airport. Some changes may be contemplated to the facilities at the airport with the possible introduction of wide-bodied jets by Trans-Australia Airlines or Ansett Airlines of Australia. I have no information at this stage about any decision on that matter. I will refer Senator Young's question to the Minister and ask him to bring down an early reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: APPROPRIATION FOR ABORIGINES IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to my question of 2 December 1980 which suggested that money appropriated by this Parliament for social support for Aboriginals in the Northern Territory may have been spent on the renovation of airstrips for a private airline company which has since been placed in receivership. The Minister replied on 23 January by letter. He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I am unable to assure you that these monies have not been used to upgrade airstrips in the Northern Territory.

Do I take it from that reply that the Minister has no knowledge of whether money appropriated by this Parliament is used for purposes other than that for which the Parliament appropriated it? Is this action proper, honest and legal? Is the Aboriginal vote being deprived of parliamentary appropriations because an airline company wants to upgrade an airstrip?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator was kind enough, before the Senate sat, to show me the particular sentence of the response so that I could confirm that those were the words I wrote. I say to the honourable senator that the answer I gave to him gives an appropriate background to the situation that exists in the Northern Territory. In the light of that answer, the sentence I wrote to the honourable senator is correct and stands.

—I ask a supplementary question. We voted the money for a specific purpose. Can a Minister decide to spend it for a purpose other than that for which the Parliament approved it? That is what I want to know. Has this Minister done so?
—I have no knowledge that the money has been spent other than in accord with the directions of the Parliament.

—I ask a question of the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the recent meeting in Canberra on, I think, the 12th of this month of Ministers concerned with water resources. I think this question in a sense is supplementary to that asked by Senator Teague. Is the Minister aware that the average annual salt load entering South Australia, excluding the wet years of 1974-75 and 1975-76, was 1.1 million tonnes? Is he also aware that in the period from 6 August 1980 to 28 January 1981 approximately 115,000 tonnes of salt or 39 per cent of the salt load originated in the Darling system in New South Wales? As this is a vital issue in South Australia, will the Minister inform the Senate when the appropriate regulation or legislation will be introduced into Parliament to give the River Murray Commission control over water quality in the River Murray system?

—As I said in response to the previous questioner, the question of both quantity and quality control of the River Murray is of vital importance to South Australia. Therefore, I acknowledge the significance of this question. I am not aware of the precise figures that Senator Jessop has given for the volume of salt. I am aware that it has been severe and of such a quantity as to cause grave concern. Senator Jessop referred to 39 per cent of salinity originating from the Darling. I can only say that of late I have read conflicting evidence, some of which challenges that assertion. In fact I have read a substantial argument that it is not so much the Darling as other sources that contribute to the volume of salt.
—The Goulburn River in Victoria.

—Yes. As I understand it, and as Senator McLaren has remarked, it comes along the tributaries from Victoria. Whether or not that is so, the real significance is that there is salt in unacceptable volumes and it has to be dealt with. So I acknowledge the substance, the thrust, of the question. I said previously that the discussion with the relevant Ministers on 12 February reached a point at which one or possibly two really significant matters remained to be resolved. We asked the States to consider the first matter. I believe that with good will we can reach a solution which will mean that the River Murray Commission will have some capacity not only to monitor flow and quality but also to comment upon any actions of significance that might alter the quality or quantity of water. I assure Senator Jessop that this matter is very much in our minds at this moment. We are as eager as he is to see that this agreement is put in place as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: APPROPRIATION FOR ABORIGINES IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, concerns the matters raised with him in Senator Cavanagh's question. In reply to the question from Senator Cavanagh concerning an allegation that Federal money approved for Aborigines had been used for airstrips, the Minister answered that he did not know whether the money had been used for airstrips. I pursue the matter now by quoting three sentences from the Minister's letter to Senator Cavanagh concerning the use of the amount of $3.042m approved by Parliament in Appropriation Act (No. 1), of which $286,000 represents the program for the Minister's Department's Northern Territory (Northern) Region. Senator Baume, in his letter to Senator Cavanagh, says:

QUESTION.PARA: I am advised that sum is fully committed against programs for the Kalano Association in Katherine and the Aboriginal Development Foundation in Darwin. The Northern Territory Government has neither control over nor access to these funds. I am unable to assure you that these monies have not been used to upgrade airstrips in the Northern Territory.

My question is this: If the money in question was not used by the Northern Territory Government and the Federal Minister cannot tell us what has happened to the funds, who is accountable to the Parliament for the expenditure of those moneys?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the honourable senator for quoting from the rest of the letter. I might even table the letter when I have given the rest of this answer. Mr President, I think it might be most appropriate if I now obtain from my Department further information. What I actually said was that I could not assure Senator Cavanagh at the time I wrote the letter that the moneys had not been used to upgrade airstrips in the Northern Territory. I will undertake to get further information for Senator Ryan.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Can he or can he not inform the Senate of the way in which money appropriated under the Appropriation Act (No. 1) for expenditure on social support for Aboriginals was expended? Does he or does he not know what has happened to that money?
—Mr President, I have nothing further to add to what I said a moment ago.

—I ask the Attorney-General: Has the Government yet determined its attitude to the recommendations of the Copyright Tribunal on increases in record royalties? If so, what are these decisions and can any action on the recommendations be expected in the near future?
—The Government has not made any decision in relation to the matter raised by Senator Puplick.
—You had better make them soon. You will get flooded with paper if you don't.

—That is the trouble. We have all been flooded with paper to such an extent that it is making the decision-making process a rather long one. The fact is that representations and counter-representations have been made. Matters have also been raised by both parties, so to speak, in relation to tribunal reports and I felt that they ought to be fully investigated. That has been a very time-consuming process indeed. I think it would be unwise to predict exactly when any decision will be made but I hope that we are coming to the end of the process.

—I ask the Attorney-General: Is it the case that character assessments are presently taking place in the Attorney-General's Department whereby all employees, including those who have no access to classified government documents, are being checked for such apparently irrelevant or ill-defined characteristics as 'undeclared homosexuality' or a 'loose tongue'? By what authority, legislative or administrative, are these checks being carried out? Are they being carried out or will they be carried out by any other department? If such action is not directly connected with the protection of highly sensitive classified material, what is the policy underlying such checks?

—Following the passage last year of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation legislation, much of the security classification work which had previously been performed by ASIO is now being carried out by individual departments. Departments are carrying out a review of security assessments which have been in force for some time. These assessments previously involved checks of records, including police records, and were made without the knowledge of the persons concerned. The new procedures seek the consent of the person being assessed before the check of police records is made. The Attorney-General's Department, I think, is the first, or certainly one of the first departments to carry out these new procedures. Forms are being prepared by my Department in conjunction with the Public Service Board. They have been sent to officers throughout Australia. I am informed that no officer who has completed the form has withheld consent or has prevented a search being made of police records. I am not in a position to answer some of the specific questions which Senator Evans has raised in relation to investigation. I will have them investigated and will provide an early answer for him.

—I ask a supplementary question. Having agreed to further investigations, will the Attorney do two things: Firstly, will he undertake to table in the Parliament forms that persons are being required to fill in and also any supporting documentation governing the procedures now applicable and, secondly, will he tell us what the fate of any member of his Department who refused to give consent to this procedure would be in practice?
—I will give further consideration to those questions as well as the other questions and will provide answers.

—I ask a question of the Minister for National Development and Energy. I previously have raised the question of aerial fire-fighting and mentioned the Canadian plane, the CL125. Has the Government, the Australian representative of the aircraft firm concerned or representatives of other firms contacted the various State governments seeking their views on the use of such a method? If so, can those views be made known? As I have been told that trials are to be undertaken, can the Minister advise the nature of the trials, the results of them and whether, if successful, Australians may have some aerial fire-fighting capability by next summer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Senator Archer's very practical interest in this matter. On 22 September of last year the Prime Minister announced that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation would undertake an assessment of the effectiveness of aerial fire-fighting techniques and he invited the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to nominate State officers to participate in the Commonwealth-funded study. Whilst some indicated that there were doubts about the effectiveness of fire-bombing techniques in conditions pertaining to their States, they all agreed to participate. The CSIRO study will not be just a demonstration of fire-bombing techniques but a thorough scientific assessment of the effectiveness of bombing fires of varying intensities with water and fire-retarding chemicals. The CSIRO will compare this technique with conventional fire-fighting methods and will conduct a cost-benefit analysis of bushfire suppression methods.

ANSWER.PARA: On 8 February the Prime Minister and the Premier of Victoria announced that the Commonwealth had agreed to a request by the Victorian Government to provide a Royal Australian Air Force Hercules aircraft for the 1981-82 bushfire season to evaluate a United States mobile airborne fire-fighting system and to fly fire-fighting missions in Victoria. The Commonwealth and Victoria will share the costs equally, and the CSIRO will be able to take full advantage of these trials and operations to collect data on bushfire behaviour and control.

I should add, however, that the Commonwealth will not confine its contribution to alleviating the problem by those means only. It will make available Defence Force equipment and personnel to assist State agencies. The value of this assistance has been amply demonstrated this summer in bushfires in two States, New South Wales and Victoria. The Commonwealth also provides funds through the national disaster assistance arrangements. These actions complement those by the States. The question which Senator Archer has raised is one of continuing interest. I will ensure that as information becomes available he is provided with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It now has been shown that golden staph is the link between the use of tampons and toxic shock syndrome that has been the cause of death of many women in America and in Europe. It is now evident that Australian women are affected and it has been shown that golden staph was present in unused tampons, part of a pack used by a woman who was taken to hospital seriously ill with toxic shock syndrome. One New Zealand firm has withdrawn one brand from sale in Australia. Will the Government therefore have all these products withdrawn from sale until they are proved safe to use and will it urgently increase research into the problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator first raised this matter in the Senate last December, at which stage I think only two cases had been reported overseas and none had been reported in Australia. During the recess a larger number of cases started to be reported around the world.

ANSWER.PARA: The first two confirmed cases of toxic shock syndrome in Australia occurred in Melbourne and Launceston. The States and Territories were notified following the first case and the NHMRC-the National Health and Medical Research Council-then issued a Press statement. Both the patients identified had used Carefree Super tampons manufactured in New Zealand by Johnson and Johnson. The Australian branch of the company recalled all stocks of New Zealand made tampons, back to retail level. Microbiological and chemical investigations on various tampons are now being conducted by the NBSL-the National Biological Standards Laboratory-in Canberra and by State research institutions.

The Centre for Disease Control in Atlanta in the United States of America has been notified of the Australian cases and has been requested to provide information on any tampon contamination discovered in the United States. Details of the first case have been published in the departmental publication Communicable Diseases Intelligence. Discussions are now being held with manufacturers and importers of tampons. I think the Department of Health is keeping a very close watching brief. The appropriate government authorities are determining whether further advice needs to be given. The honourable senator will recall that I said all stocks of the tampon in question were withdrawn by Johnson and Johnson. I assure her that the investigation is being taken very seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I gather that the answer to my question is: 'No, the Government will not withdraw materials from sale until they have been proved safe and the Government will not increase urgent research into these problems'.

—First of all, I repeat what I said: A large number of tampons have been withdrawn. I think the other parts of the honourable senator's question as to whether there should be a more general withdrawal from sale or whether more general measures should be taken should be referred to my colleague, the Minister for Health, to see whether he has anything to add.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. What, in days, is the target set by the Government for reserves of liquid hydrocarbons in Australia? What is the present holding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a variety of different answers, depending upon the particular hydrocarbons in question. I shall answer in terms of crude oil itself which is the source of the hydrocarbons and therefore the available source for refining to produce on-the-spot supplies. Australia is seeking to improve upon what has been an IEA-International Energy Agency-goal of stock for some 70 to 80 days. We hope to get to, say, 90 days. Because we have Bass Strait, the best way of storing crude oil is in indigenous wells, provided that disaster or industrial unrest does not disturb it. In general we have been able to reach the equivalent of some 70 days stocks.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a variety of answers in relation to the remainder of the hydrocarbons. My Department published yesterday the first of a series of monthly statistics which showed, for example, a decline, I think in January, in the gasoline stocks compared with the same period last year. That had a lot to do with industrial conditions.

The stocks of refined products are not as significant in terms of the number of days if one can be assured of two things-that there will not be industrial unrest and that there will not be damage to refineries. We have set out on a policy of asking the companies to increase their storage on both the crude side and the product side of the refinery and in particular products. Today we have overcome the shortage of avgas. We do not have to import it. In fact, we are producing a surplus of avgas. We have good stocks available.

The significant challenge to us at the moment is to produce more distillate, which is the fuel in greatest demand and which we need to have adequate stocks of, but at the same time not to produce a surplus of gasolene. My answer to Senator MacGibbon's question is that we would hope to publish statistics monthly. The stocks held by companies have been regarded as confidential. Some pressure has been but upon us by Senate committees-I think by Senator Thomas's committee in particular-to reveal the figures. We are doing so. I think that is good for the public dialogue. If there are specific stocks of products which Senator MacGibbon is interested in I would be happy to furnish him with the information he requires.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It relates to the expulsion of 50 Aboriginals from the property known as Gordon Downs, in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, which is owned by Mr Peter Sherwin. The West Australian of 16 January quoted the Minister as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I am concerned about the expulsion or removal of any traditional Aboriginal people from land with which they have strong ties. My Department has sent an officer from Kunanurra to Halls Creek to investigate all matters concerned with the reported expulsion. He will be reporting to me as soon as possible.

Therefore, I ask the Minister whether that officer has now reported on the Gordon Downs matter, what action has been taken as a result of that report and what action will be taken by the Federal Government in the future to safeguard Aboriginal rights in relation to traditional homes on station properties, particularly in the State of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —An officer of my Department did go to the area and did consult with the Aboriginal people. It has been quite difficult in the last few weeks, because of the wet, to travel in the area around Halls Creek to get to Gordon Downs and to complete the consultation. Although Aboriginals have a right of entry on to pastoral stations in Western Australia, the pastoralists are not compelled to provide services or accommodation for them. The matter of the people from Gordon Downs is properly one for the West Australian Government. That Government--
—You ought to sack Court.

—It might be worth listening to my reply because the Gordon Downs group has told my officers that it has no wish to return to the station. The West Australian Government has decided, as a first step, to make a temporary reserve of 3,500 hectares available to the group at a place called Ringers Soak-while it considers possible options for the longer term future of the community. Previously, while there was no tenure for members of the Aboriginal community on Gordon Downs, we were reluctant to provide certain support services for them.
—Why?

—Because had we provided the services we would have had no rights over them; they would have become the property of someone else. With the granting of a temporary reserve the Commonwealth will be providing grants to allow a satisfactory water supply to be established at the site chosen by the group. It will be supplying resources to provide other basic facilities, although again because of the wet season there are difficulties in getting this work carried out as early as we would like. The work will commence as soon as the wet season conditions allow and as soon as the group wants to return from Halls Creek.

—Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question. The Minister said 'on a site chosen by the group'. I just question whether the site he has referred to is Ringers Soak. If the Minister is saying that that is the site that has been chosen by the group let me say to him that that is not so, and he knows it is not so. The group has chosen part of Gordon Downs and part of another pastoral lease to be excised from both of those and part of Crown land which the State Government of Western Australia has refused to hand over to the group. Is the site chosen by the group to which the Minister is referring known as Ringers Soak? If so, it has nothing whatsoever to do with the community that I am talking about from Gordon Downs.

—I have been advised by my officers who have been in the area and who have spoken to the Aboriginals that the answer I gave is correct-that the Aboriginal people who were so cruelly expelled from Gordon Downs do not wish to return to the station and that they do wish to settle at the site chosen by the group, a site called Yaruman or Ringers Soak. That is my advice. I have no reason to doubt that that it is correct.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Government regard the three very successful Liberal Party wins in the by-elections on Saturday and in particular the swing to the Government in the division of Boothby as yet another significant public endorsement of the Fraser Government's policies? Has further disarray and disunity come upon the Australian Labor Party as a result of the very poor showing by ALP candidates on Saturday?
—I raise a point of order. Does this matter fall within the responsibility of the Minister?
—That depends on the Minister's assessment of the question.
—I am asked, I think, a question of fact. The fact is that the results of the by-elections are in parallel with the results at the ballot box last October. They are--
—Mr President, I raise another point of order. If a question of fact which is not within the Minister's portfolio is asked is there any need for an answer? What Senator Teague has said is a fact.
—Ministers respond to matters which come within their own areas of responsibility.

—Mr President, I represent the Prime Minister. I take it that this matter falls within my area of responsibility. I repeat, on the facts the results on Saturday are in parallel with the results last October-highly satisfactory.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Government, as a result of election promises, is overcommitted to the amount of $8m in respect of the funding of child care community services and is now unable to provide this funding with the result that many established child care centres are in danger of shutting down unless the respective State governments continue interim funding? If this is the position, what action does he, as the Minister responsible, intend taking to ensure that existing child care centres do not have to close?

—The position is that the child care program is continuing to make payments in accordance with the commitments which had been entered into. It is a fact that at the moment the program is overcommitted. It is not as high as the one mentioned by the honourable senator. I think it is more in the vicinity of $7m. That is a matter which is being examined in more detail at the moment. All projects which were being funded at the beginning of the year, as I understand it, are continuing to be funded on the basis on which funding was originally agreed. The questions which are arising are questions as to the funding of new projects. In this respect I intend to make no decisions until the position in respect of the present commitments is clarified and until I have had a chance to examine the total new claims which are likely to be made on the program, and they are considerable. There is therefore likely to be a delay of some time before any new commitments are entered into.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer the Minister to the fact that in 1977 the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications, Mr Robinson, asserted in the House of Representatives the importance of a broadcasting system 'not subject to political interference' and that the same assertion was made in this House by Senator Carrick as the Minister representing the Minister for Post and Telecommunications in this House. TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday last, 20 February, Mr John Kerr, the Principal Parliamentary Reporter, retired. Mr Kerr began his public service with the New South Wales Department of Lands in 1936. In 1949 he began his reporting career with the Commonwealth Reporting Service in Sydney. He entered parliamentary service in 1950 when he was appointed as a reporter on the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. Mr Kerr progressed through the ranks of Hansard and was appointed Principal Parliamentary Reporter in 1978. In 1942 Mr Kerr enlisted in the Citizen Military Forces. He later transferred to the Australian Imperial Force and saw service in Papua and New Guinea. Upon the cessation of hostilities in the Pacific he served for a short time in Australia assisting to gather and prepare evidence for presentation to the War Crimes Tribunal.

INTERJECT.PARA: In his leisure time Mr Kerr has been active as an author of both books and plays. Several of his books have been published and some have been adapted for broadcasting by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. His plays too have been broadcast by the ABC and some have been performed in public in Canberra. In his retirement Mr Kerr will not be idle; he will be pursuing tertiary studies at the Australian National University and will continue to write books and plays.

I am sure all honourable senators join me in thanking John Kerr for his long and valued service to the Parliament. We wish him and his wife a long and rewarding retirement. Mr Kerr's successor as Principal Parliamentary Reporter is Mr James Roberts, whose assistant will be Mr John Campbell.

I begin briefly by expressing my indebtedness to Senator Carrick for doing something to assuage my anger which I had in respect not only of him but also of Ministers generally this evening when it was brought home to me once again how absurd our procedure is in relation to these reports which are not made available as a matter of current practice, although it has been the case in the past. An absurd situation arises in respect of these reports. Senators, particularly Opposition senators, are obliged to make some response not days or weeks after the presentation of these reports but as a practical matter on the occasion of their tabling because that is when, obviously, they come to public significance. That is the occasion when it is necessary as a practical matter for some response to be made; not that it can ever be a very informed response with reports of this size. That has been my experience and that of my fellow front benchers. This matter demands attention. As I said, I am indebted to Senator Carrick for his expression of willingness to give, in fact, some consideration to this aspect perhaps in the context of a reference to the Senate Standing Orders Committe ultimately so we can get some rationality in what has long been an irrational aspect of our procedure.

Having said all that there is obviously not much I can do by way of drawing attention to particular matters in the short time I have had available to look at the report. Two points stick out even on the very cursory opportunity I have had to look at the report. I take the opportunity to suggest that in all the circumstances of this matter the Prime Minister should now table the Ombudsman's report to him indicating the nature of the Ombudsman's legitimate, as it proves, objections to the departmental head's behaviour and making a matter of complete public record something of a conclusion to a chapter of events which has been a very sorry state of affairs for quite some years.
