I wish to make a few comments in respect of this report. One thing which disturbed me greatly was that in a letter which was dated 5 December and which, I guess, went to all members of the Parliament we were told that the Australian National Railways had changed its title to Australian National. The report tabled tonight is the annual report of the Australian National Railways Commission. Yet on 5 December we were notified for some unknown and, to many people, very confusing reason that the Australian National Railways is now known as Australian National. When I had occasion to telephone the ANR the girl who answered the telephone said: 'Australian National'. I had to ask her: 'Australian National what?' Members of the public would not know to whom they were talking-whether it was a shipping company, an airline company, a medical benefits company or whatever. It could be anything at all. It could even stand for Australian National Parliament. Why on earth should the Australian National Railways want to bury its identity under the title Australian National? It is absolute stupidity. Nobody knew anything about it until the Parliament rose and we got this letter. I would like to know who made this decision. Is it a decision of Mr Hunt's? Other decisions that he has made have forced the Australian National Railways to close down many country rail services and to run dead carriages on the Indian Pacific and the Transcontinental, about which I will say a few words in a moment.

This matter causes great concern not only to me but also to other people in Australia who had taken great pride in the Australian national railway system. We now find that it is no longer to be known as a railway system; it is to be known just as Australian National. Of course that cannot be at other than the behest of this Government. This Government's record proves that it has a dead set against the railway system and that it would like to see the railway system put completely out of existence with the carriage of all goods in Australia handed over to private road hauliers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are we spending so many millions on the Alice Springs to Darwin rail line? That is a stupid statement.

—Some of the figures in this report that I will read out prove the Government's record in this regard. I make the comment that the report we are now debating is signed by Mr Keith Smith, the Acting Chairman of the Australian National Railways Commission. It is the last report he will sign on behalf of the Commission because he has now retired. I would like to place on record my commendation of Mr Smith for the wonderful work he did for the railway system of Australia. I am sure that he would not have been in complete agreement with taking out of the title the word 'Railways'. Mr Smith did a very good job and on any occasion on which I had to speak with him on any matter dealing with the conditions of employees or anything to do with railways I always got a very courteous hearing. I am sure that all railway employees would agree with me that he did his best to look after their interests despite the fact that this present Government imposed great pressures on the railways.

SPEECH.PARA: The report shows that for 1978-79 passenger operations amounted to $1,528,413,000 whilst for the last financial year, that is, 1979-80, the amount had dropped to $1,467,455,000. So the ANR had suffered a drop in revenue despite an increase in fares. Why was there that drop? It happened because at the behest of this Government the ANR is running dead cars on the east-west service, that is, the Indian Pacific and the Transcontinental. I have first hand information about this because recently when my wife and I tried to book on the Indian Pacific from Perth back to South Australia-I had been in Perth on a Senate standing committee-I was told that we could not get a double berth; we could get only two single berths. On making further inquiries I found that the system used by the railways was to allocate so many berths and then to allocate the rest of them to tourist bureaus. No check is made to see whether the tourist bureaus sell all the seats made available to them but upon ringing the railways one is told that they have sold all their quota and that no seats are available. When I travelled on the train I spoke to some of the people who worked on it. I found that on the return trip there are dead cars on the train and that the railway is paying staff 60 per cent of their normal wages to travel back from Parkeston to Port Pirie as passengers because the cars are not full. Why on earth cannot these cars be full? People wanted to get seats on the Indian Pacific or on the Transcontinental but no seats were available. So the railway is not doing the job it ought to be doing in selling itself to the general public and promoting the rail service it offers. I say the service it offers is second to none anywhere in the world. Over the years I have had the privilege of travelling on European railways and none of them which offers overnight accommodation can offer the service which is offered to the Australian travelling public or to visitors to Australia either on the Indian Pacific or on the Transcontinental. We hear honourable senators on the other side of the chamber say that we have to promote tourism. I say here and now that the Australian National Railways is not promoting tourism, because it could fill those trains every time they ran if it went about it in the proper way. Senator Jessop interrupted me and said that--

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't know what you are talking about. You make me sick.

—His Government is now constructing a railway line or is going to construct one from Alice Springs to Darwin. I say to him that if the Government is going to adopt the same attitude with that train when it starts to run as the railways are adopting with the Indian Pacific and the Transcontinental, that line will run at a loss also. I could have a great argument with Senator Jessop about my making him sick. Ever since I have been a member of this Parliament he has made me sick with some of the outlandish statements he has put out and which he cannot back up. Senator Jessop cannot rebut the remarks I have made tonight in regard to the way in which the Australian National Railways is operating in running dead cars on the system. That is why it is running at a loss. Senator Jessop ought to talk to some of the railway employees who work these trains and who live in the electorate he used to represent until the people got sick of him and elected Mr Wallis and hear what they have to say about the Railways Commission operating those two passenger trains.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer now to what the ANR is doing to the freight service. It is killing its freight service as well as killing small business. From the way in which it puts up freight charges it is obvious that it does not want the small freight items to be carried on the railway. It is giving away the source of revenue to private road hauliers, and Senator Jessop cannot deny it. It is losing as much as 50 per cent patronage in the carriage of parcels. I raised in the Parliament before it rose for the Christmas recess the case of a man who runs a dry-cleaning business in my home town of Murray Bridge and who complained to me that it was costing a customer who lived at Tailem Bend, which is about 16 miles from Murray Bridge, up to $6.50 to send a suit from Tailem Bend to Murray Bridge by rail to have it dry-cleaned and returned. It cost so much because the railways do not want to carry small packages. I have had it proved to me that a massive piece of freight can be sent from Adelaide to Murray Bridge for the same cost as that of sending a small parcel because the lowest charge that the railways now make for a small parcel is $4 to $5, irrespective of the size.

It need be the size of only an envelope but that is what one has to pay if it is put on the rail passenger service. The railway is killing small business. Yet Senator Jessop is always prating about the interest that his Government has in small business. It is quite obvious that people such as Senator Jessop do not confer with people who run small businesses in South Australia. They are being run out of business as far as freight charges by the railways are concerned. The railways ought to be there to give a service to the people, not to make a profit. As I pointed out, it is stated in this report that has been tabled tonight that the ANR is earning less revenue even though its charges have increased. This is because it is chasing people away from using its services.

Many primary producers in South Australia have written to me-no doubt they have also written to Senator Jessop but he has never raised this matter in the Parliament; it is left to members of the Opposition-expressing concern at the closure of country services. But Senator Jessop does not tell us about that. All he thinks about is getting money for roads. The next thing we will hear from Senator Jessop in here will be a request to the Government to set up a special fund, something like that which Mr Sinclair talked about for the Stuart Highway, to construct roads in the Murray-Mallee region once the train services are curtailed then finished so that the farmers in the region can cart their stock, their grain and their superphosphate on roads in the winter time because there are no suitable roads there now. The only way one can satisfactorily service those people's needs is by way of a railway system. Under the direction of Mr Hunt, those railway services are closing down, and the present State Minister in charge of railways in South Australia, Mr Wilson, is doing nothing to prevent it. Mr Virgo would not agree with the Federal Government; he would not allow it to close the lines. That is one of the penalties that the people in South Australia are paying for having a State Liberal government. I will read from a letter which I have received, which will form a petition to be signed by thousands of people in the country areas of South Australia and which will be presented to the State Parliament with the name 'Mr Hunt' deleted and replaced by the name 'Mr Wilson' as Transport Minister. This letter reads thus:
Mr Hunt.Federal Minister for Transport.
We, the Undersigned,
Whole-heartedly disagree with the way the Australian National-Rail, is deliberately running down the country rail services in this State.

Increasing freight and parcel rates to such an extent that people are now turning to Australia-Post and road transport. The ludicrous point being that Australian National-Rail has contracts to carry Australia-Post parcels, mail-bags and goods at ridiculous freight rates.

We believe that the administration of Australian National-Rail are intentionally destroying country rail services in this State, under the direction of the Federal Minister for Transport, in a bid to strip the rail services to country people, by forcing them to use other means.

We believe that by the implementation of the above, Australian National-Rail is achieving its aim of not employing men and women in place of those who resign or retire, at the expense of those who are desperately in need of permanent employment for the security of their families and family life.

We wish to remind the Australian National-Rail Administration and Mr Hunt, that the railways in this State were placed here as a service to the country people and for those people in semi-isolated and isolated areas.

We wish to remind the Federal Minister for Transport Mr Hunt, and Australian National-Rail, that country businesses are suffering under these freight increases and are being forced to inflate their prices to cover transport costs for normal everyday consumables.
We demand that the Australian National-Rail reduce freight and parcel rates to a fair and reasonable charge.

We demand that rather than turn people away from the railway service with these excessive charges, that the opposite should occur and every encouragement should be given to people and businesses to use the railway as much as possible.
We demand that a review of the above be taken and adjusted immediately.

They are just echoing the words which I have spoken in the Parliament on many occasions about Australia's railway services. The railways were first constructed in this country to give a service to the people and to develop the country. Yet we now find people in government who say that the user has to pay. If that had been the policy when the east-west railway was first constructed under a Labor government many years ago where would we have been in the last world war conflict? As a member of the Australian forces at that time I made many trips across the Nullarbor Plain in troop trucks. If that line had not been built by the foresight of the Labor Government how would we have got across? There was no road. Of course, shipping was in danger because of mines, and many ships were sunk off the Australian coast. So the Australian defence forces could not have been deployed from east to west if it had not been for the foresight of a Labor government.

If he does, I will go back to those people very shortly to talk to them. So will Mr Wallis and Senator Robertson, who is very concerned about the service now being operated between Tarcoola and Alice Springs, to see whether in fact there are any dead cars running. As Senator Jessop has said, the Government has made the announcement that it will construct the remainder of the link from Alice Springs to Darwin.

I am not the only one who is concerned about the way in which the Government is operating the railway system. I have an advertisement out of the Border Chronicle, a paper which is often quoted from in the Senate. It is published at Bordertown. The advertisement states:
Bordertown Chamber of Commerce
Dinner Meeting
Woolshed Inn
On Monday, February 16-
that is last week-
at 7 p.m. . .
Meeting to discuss freight alternatives.

Freight alternatives! So those people too are concerned about what the Government is doing to our magnificent railway system. If the Government had any sense at all, the first thing it would do to try to eliminate some of the unemployment in this country would be to set about constructing a dual track, firstly between Adelaide and Melbourne so that we could run a service quickly there. I am reliably informed by people who have worked in the railways for most of their working lives that one cannot travel any quicker now on a passenger train from Adelaide to Melbourne than one could on the first day that the first train ran along the track. That is brought about because of the cross-overs. Passenger trains have to wait in sidings for freight trains to pass. I have said on many occasions in the Parliament that what we ought to do to create an increase in employment and to update our business enterprises is to set about constructing a dual track between those two capital cities. When that is done we could commence, in conjunction with the upgrading of the Crystal Brook railway line, to put down a dual track to Perth in Western Australia so that we will have a railway service which will run some of these great juggernauts off the road.

Reports tabled in this Parliament show that among those people with the highest rates of bankruptcy are those who have borrowed money to buy and run these great transports. Before they know where they are they are run out of business. They have ruined not only their own lives but also the lives of their families and of many people with whom they have contracted to cart freight. They go flat because they cannot compete. They are all cutting one another's throats. They are driving day and night seven days a week to try to make ends meet, whereas in the railways system people work proper hours and have happier families. The husband is home so many nights a week with his wife and family, whereas the truck driver may be anywhere between Perth and Darwin or in Townsville or Cairns. He is rarely ever at home. This is the problem that we are faced with.

I say again that I cannot understand-perhaps the Minister can explain it to me-why the Australian National Railways Commission had to change its title by dropping the word 'Railways'. I think that most concerned people in Australia have been proud of our railway system. I do not know the reason for dropping the word 'Railways' and neither do many people to whom I have spoken. I hope that the answers to some of my questions will be given before I am forced to raise them again. I do not know whether Senator Jessop wishes to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in what some people may regard as a somewhat unaccustomed role, as a defender of a statutory authority and a defender of the Government. Senator Chaney expresses his surprise that I should do that. I think Senator McLaren's comments need answering. He has obviously misunderstood what has been happening. I think it is important that it be understood. Whether it is agreed with is another question. He asserted that the change in the name of the Australian National Railways Commission to Australian National was obviously implemented at the behest of this Government which has a set against the railways. It appears that Senator McLaren-
—That new name is a Madison Avenue gimmick.

—The honourable senator is displaying a greater capacity to be with it than is Senator McLaren. Some of the statutory authorities-the Australian National Railways Commission is one of them-have followed the course taken by a large cross-section of the major private enterprise trading establishments in Australia in engaging consultants who are corporate image experts, people who can examine the total operation of an organisation and try to get an identification from both a staff and a customer point of view with something that is described-I do not profess to be an expert-as corporate image.
—Why didn't you leave it as Australian National Railways?

—I did not do it. I am not the corporate image expert. A large number of major corporations have decided to engage the services of a very well known man, Mr Pieter Huveneers, and his company to advise them on an expert basis as to the whole question of corporate image with a view to improving-I was trying to describe this-both the staff and employee relationships and association with the undertaking and also the customer association. Instead of the Myer Emporium we have Myer. That is one example. Instead of Trans-Australia Airlines, we would have Trans-Australia. That also is a suggestion from the same corporate image expert. The same advisers have suggested a whole number of steps which are related to the improvement of the corporate image of the Australian National Railways Commission. As a statutory authority the Australian National Railways Commission is entitled to act independently in the engagement of such professional services, and, as I understand it, it has acted independently in the engagement of those services, with a view to trying to develop a much greater degree of identity and esprit de corps within the railway service itself and a better association of the public mind with the operation which is being undertaken. It may be that Senator McLaren and other senators do not undertand this or think it is a bit way out or something else.
—I just would not know what 'Australian National' meant.

—Senator Coleman says that she would not know what 'Australian National' meant. I guess that for a period a great many people will not know what it means. The point is that the Commission is entitled to engage people who have a reputation and an expertise which have been accepted Australia-wide by a large cross-section. Whether or not we agree with the advice which has been given, I want to tell both Senator McLaren and the Senate that it is not some Government gimmick to destroy the railways, but rather the advice of the best known major private consultant--
—What did he charge for that advice?

—I imagine that the compensation would be adequate. The name change is only part of a total program. I have recently discussed all of this with the expert concerned. As I understand it, it involves a total approach to the whole of a corporate undertaking, whether it be a company or a statutory authority which is engaged in commercial activity, to bring together a wide cross-section of factors which it is believed-obviously, a large number of private sector people believed that this was a good idea-will improve its identification both for employees and for customers. If honourable senators are concerned about this, perhaps it would be more useful to have some discussion about it at a forthcoming Estimates Committee meeting as to what is intended. Senator McLaren, who raised this matter, apparently does not have the interest in the explanation which he sought.
—Because your information is not good enough. You have lost the identity of the railways. That is what I am complaining about.

—I am trying to explain that I have not done anything about the railways. I was trying to let Senator McLaren know what a statutory authority, given a degree of independence by the Parliament, has in its wisdom decided to do, along with a number of other things that it is doing, to try to improve the performance of its total activities. Through the independent choice which the Commission has, not only has it made a decision in relation to its corporate image but it has also undertaken, I believe rather successfully, a lot of the reorganisation of its total activity. Perhaps it ought to be congratulated for showing a degree of spirit and endeavouring to be both competitive and reasonably successful in reducing an ever-growing subsidy which it was projected would reach by 1982, I think it was, well over $100m and which has now been cut down to about $60m. It is providing a service and developing and is employing a large number of people. It believes-I am prepared to accept this on the basis of 'let us give it a try'-that it is improving the identity and association of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is good enough for a large number of private enterprise companies to engage services and successfully to follow up the advice which they have received, then let one or two statutory authorities also engage such services and accept the advice which they receive. Let us see what happens when TAA becomes Trans-Australia. Let us see what happens when Australian National Railways becomes Australian National. I simply wish to point out that it is not a matter of attacking the Government for trying to destroy the railways. It is a matter of identifying the fact that the Australian National Railways Commission has sought and obtained advice. This proposal follows the advice which it has received. Let us give it a go rather than attack it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prompted to rise to my feet because of some of the remarks made by Senator McLaren. In his usual succinct, careful and moderated language he has drawn to our attention a few matters that I think ought to be replied to. One matter which really annoyed me was his accusation that the present Federal Government has disregarded the importance of railways to Australia and is intent on diverting rail traffic to road transport. That remark deserves a reply because it is quite unfounded and quite untrue. If Senator McLaren were to observe the record of the Fraser Government in these matters he would recognise that the opposite is the case. I recall having some interest in the matter of the construction of a railway line from Tarcoola to Alice Springs. Because of the interest in that development the Federal Government agreed to provide additional funding so that that railway could be completed 12 months ahead of schedule. It was opened in October of last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, the Federal Government decided that it was quite important in the interest of the development of South Australia and the Northern Territory to proceed as rapidly as possible with the construction of the standardised link between Crystal Brook and Adelaide. In fairly recent times this Parliament approved finance of approxi- mately $68m so that that project can continue. It is anticipated that the project will be completed by about 1982 or 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy-two years after the agreement was signed--

—The honourable senator interjects and tells us how the Labor Government built a road from Alice Springs to Darwin. He forgot to mention that the United States of America had some interest in that road and that because of international finance it was able to complete that road. I give credit to the Labor Government for using the financial capacity of other countries to achieve that road. I draw attention to the fact also that during the latest election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stated that we would proceed with the construction of the railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin at a cost of approximately $400m. SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator McLaren stated also that certain lines had to be closed down. He and Mr Dunstan decided to flog the railways to the Whitlam Government. The Whitlam Government bought the railways at a cost of $800m or more. Therefore, we as a government have had to persist with that. The Australian National Railways Commission is now to be called Australian National. It will not take long for Opposition senators, even with their intelligence, to realise the significance of the change. I can recognise it and can quite easily come to grips with the change in terminology. We are proceeding ahead. I think the Australian National is doing a job that is quite creditable. I was ashamed of the honourable senator when he denigrated the efforts being put forward by the Australian National with regard to the need to become a viable organisation within 10 years. That is what our Government decided to do. We believe it is important that if we provide these facilities to the people they use them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are taking the facilities away from the people, as I explained.

—The honourable senator talks in a moderated and pleasant fashion, as he usually does, when interjecting during my speeches. I will return to the subject and try to talk with reasoned common sense. I suggest that if Senator McLaren is worried about any railway being closed down he should encourage people to use it. The reason we use taxpayers' money to provide these facilities is so that people will use them. I know many farmers and station owners who choose to use their own transport rather than the railways. If we can persuade them to use the facilities that we provide and if we have more than one or two passengers riding on a railway train from, say, Terowie to Adelaide perhaps it will not be necessary for lines to be closed down. Despite what might have been inferred, I have been responsible for delaying decisions with respect to the closure of certain railway lines in South Australia in order to give an opportunity to re-examine proposals and to look at the volume of freight that is flowing from these areas into the centres of concern. Despite the fact that it has been suggested that I do not raise these individual cases in parliament, a lot of effort has been going on in the background.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to dramatise the whole issue, as some honourable senators on the Opposition side choose to do. These matters can be worked out by reasoned conversation with efficient officials of the Australian National. I will continue to operate in that way to the satisfaction of the people who choose to come to me with their problems. Therefore, I suggest that the record of the Fraser Government is clear. We are prepared to promote the interest of an efficient Australian railway system. I would like to see, as a next step, a standardised link between Adelaide and Melbourne. I think that is a project we ought to proceed with as a matter of urgency. I believe the transport projects that have been initiated and carried out, and will continue to be carried out, by this Government will be in the best interests of Australia and in particular to the mutual development of South Australia and the Northern Territory. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement on a pleasant subject. The statement relates to the Prince of Wales and it has already been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in another place.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Monarchy is interwoven in Australian life in a very real and vital way. The Crown is part of our constitutional processes of Government. Feeling for the Royal family is deep-seated in the emotions of many Australians, and we all share and enjoy the public occasions which add colour to our contemporary scene. Each of us can look back on events in our own lifetime affecting the Royal family and they stand out in our memories. Tonight is such an occasion. Her Majesty the Queen has announced from Buckingham Palace the engagement of his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales to Lady Diana Spencer. The announcement has been conveyed to His Excellency the Governor-General and to the Australian Government. On behalf of the Government, and all Australians, the Prime Minister has welcomed the announcement with great pleasure and we all extend congratulations and good wishes to Prince Charles and Lady Diana.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not able to say that the announcement has caught the Australian people entirely unaware or unprepared. The media has assisted us in, at times, graphic detail. But thus prepared I can say with even greater assurance that we applaud the announcement and look forward with excitement to the pageantry of a Royal wedding. Australian people hold Prince Charles in special regard. From the completion of his schooling here as a young man, and his subsequent five visits to Australia, we have come to recognise and applaud his sense of humour and his dedication, his outgoing personality and his concern for people. He has spoken many times of his affection for Australia and Australians. We have a great affection for him, in which his wife-to-be will now share. Prince Charles will be visiting Australia again later this year and he will be given a warm welcome. I do not know whether we might have the great pleasure of welcoming Lady Diana to Australia but whenever that is, I am certain that the welcome will be equally warm, equally affectionate.

Mr President, the Crown gives us a focal point in our development as a nation and links us with our history and our origins. The significance of the monarchy is not diminishing. It is not fading in Australian consciousness. The Queen and her family are part of a living and relevant institution, which in Australia is very much tied to our own institutions and emotions. We all share with Her Majesty the Queen and Prince Philip, and the other members of the Royal family, the joy of this particular occasion and to them also we extend our good wishes. The Prime Minister will be conveying our sentiments to Prince Charles and Lady Diana, and to Her Majesty the Queen, on behalf of all Australians. I am sure he will have the wholehearted support of all members of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Carrick said that nobody was taken by surprise by this announcement. I must confess that I was. I simply say on behalf of the Opposition that we wish Prince Charles and Lady Diana well as indeed we would wish anyone well who is to get married.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator McLaren-Mr President, I seek clarification. Earlier I had been given leave by the Senate to move a motion in respect of the annual report of the Australian National Railways Commission. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion in respect of items 4 to 9 inclusive as set out on the list as circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The reports dealing with the local government grants commissions relate to the six States and the implementation of Commonwealth legislation pursuant to the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976. In our consideration of the matters now before the Senate we are in the same position as referred to by Senator Evans when he spoke earlier this evening on the annual report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I heard the Government Whip and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) suggest that the present procedures in respect of the presentation of papers are no different from those which existed in previous years. In the five years I have been a member of the front bench in this place it has been the practice of the Government to make available to the Opposition copies of the papers to be presented to the Senate in sufficient time for honourable senators at least to have a cursory examination of the reports to enable us to comment on them following their presentation. That is not the position with these reports. Although the Opposition Whip was able, just prior to Senator Evans' speaking on the annual report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, to get a copy of the 1980-81 report of the New South Wales Grants Commission on financial assistance for local government, we were not able to get copies of the other reports.

I suggest that it is the responsibility of the Government to revert to the system that used to operate in this place instead of having the present haphazard and slipshod system of reports being presented to the Senate which have not been made available to members on either side of the Parliament. That makes it impossible for us to make any reasonable comment upon the reports. As my colleague Senator Evans indicated, a report of some 200 pages was made available to him only minutes before he had to make some comment upon it. If it is the desire of the Government that these reports and all the work that goes into them should be put away in a pigeon-hole and referred to at some future time and not debated in the Parliament, it should continue the practice of present Ministers. If, however, it is the intention of the Parliament that both the Opposition and the Government should have an opportunity to make some comments upon these reports, I suggest there is a need to revert to the previous procedure which I am sure the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) will recall was in practice when he was Government Whip. These reports were made available to the Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip's office on the morning on which they were to be presented to the Parliament. They could be considered by the appropriate shadow Minister or members of the Opposition so that there was a purpose in the Parliament having these matters presented before it.

Speaking in relation to this report, local government has, in fact, different practices from State to State. For example, in 1968 the New South Wales Government established its own Grants Commission. Other States were to follow slowly but surely. Each State has a different attitude to the way in which local government operates in the respective States. The areas within the States vary considerably. The areas vary region by region. Of course, State by State local government develops in a considerably different way. Yet the purpose of the Commonwealth legislation was to bring about an equalisation of services in local government. It has taken us several hours today to get a copy of this report which relates to the Grants Commission of New South Wales. It is impossible for me, therefore, to make any comment upon the other States because those reports are not available. If members of the Opposition are interested in the way in which the grants commissions are operating, surely it is not asking too much of the Government to make these six reports available in sufficient time for us to do some reading of them, to make some assessment of them, to make some comments upon them in a logical and common-sense way and to assess the worth of the report and the progress of the various State commissions.

I think it has to be said that we are talking about the Government's intention, which was implicit in the legislation that we dealt with and which sought to bring about some equalisation. How can we deal with that matter today when local government in every State is having grave difficulties in raising its loan funds because of the increase in interest rates and the fact that local and semi-government bodies are vying for public funds in some sort of a bargain basement rate fashion? Consequently, because electricity authorities, for example, and other public authorities in the States are able to offer higher rates of interest than those granted to local government, every local government body without exception is reporting that it is experiencing grave difficulties in meeting its loan requirements. These requirements were granted by the Australian Loan Council. But the local government authorities are not, because of the state of the money market, able to raise the necessary funds to meet their requirements. That has disastrous consequences if the present difficulty is maintained. That will mean that local government will not be able to maintain its range of services and may well be forced into a position of disposing of its staff, of sacking those members of its work force who would otherwise be involved in its works programs.

It is not much use talking about the success of the Commonwealth Grants Commission legislation and the role the States play in the disbursement of the funds made available through the income tax sharing system. If, in fact, what I am saying is borne out-I am led to believe that this is the current position-the Parliament would need to consider very seriously whether the funds currently being made available by the Commonwealth to the States, which, as honourable senators will be aware, were increased from 1.75 per cent to 2 per cent in the Budget of last year, are totally inadequate, having regard to the failure of local government to meet its loan borrowings as provided for by the decisions of the Premiers Conference in 1980. One finds it difficult to make any specific comment about the six reports other than to say that the Government would be well advised, if it wants the Parliament to exercise both its prerogative and its responsibilities, to revert to the procedures whereby at least the Opposition, if not Government members, would have the opportunity of making some comments upon these various reports.

It may be argued by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that some of these reports would have been circulated during the recess period. But, Mr President, as you well know, it was not the circulation of the reports that offered us the problem. It was a question of selecting from the great variety of reports that were available which reports were likely to be placed before the Parliament. That becomes a task of some magnitude from the point of view of the members of the Senate. Therefore, there is a need for the procedures to be very carefully examined by the Government so that we can have those reports which require to be presented to the Parliament presented in such a way as would enable us on this side of the chamber-I am sure this was the case in the previous matter which Senator McLaren raised about government members also making an input to a report-to have adequate opportunity to have these matters properly raised in this place and subsequently set aside for the purpose of a more meaningful debate later. As I do not have available to me the reports other than that for my own State, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Whaling: Catch Quota of Minke Whales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: What International Whaling Commission supervision exists to see that neither the Japanese or USSR whalers exceed their catch quota of 3120 minke whales in the Antarctic in the period until February 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed by my Department as follows:

Under the provisions of the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling 1946, by which the International Whaling Commission (IWC) was established, catch limits are agreed at meetings of the Commission. The catch limits are incorporated into the Schedule to the Convention and become binding unless objections are lodged by individual contracting Governments within 90 days of the meeting at which the catch limits are established. Under Article IX of the 1946 Convention, each contracting Government has the responsibility of taking appropriate measures to ensure the application of the Convention, including catch limits and other provisions incorporated in the Schedule. It is the individual responsibility of contracting Governments to ensure that any infractions are punished.

In 1972 the IWC established the International Observer Scheme, under which bilateral agreements for the provision of observers are negotiated between Contracting Governments. In 1979 the Commission reviewed the operation of the International Observer Scheme and concluded that the present mechanism of bilateral agreements operated satisfactorily. Provision has now been made for any Contracting Government willing to negotiate bilateral agreements to notify the Commission's Secretariat, where a list of such Governments is maintained, which is available to whaling nations wishing to negotiate observer agreements. Observers report to the IWC. Reports from observers are considered by the Commission at its annual meetings, together with the annual reports of infractions required of Contracting Governments.
The USSR and Japan have an agreement which will apply in 1980-81 for the exchange of observers for their Southern Hemisphere pelagic operations.

Pelagic catches will be monitored on factory ships by the observers exchanged between the USSR and Japan and the reports of the observers will be considered by the IWC at its next annual meeting in July 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Do aged married couples who are occupants of separate nursing homes receive the single rate pension because of their separate circumstances for pension purposes and, for income test purposes, is the allowable income level applied at the married rate of $1794 per annum; instead of a single rate of $1040 per annum; if so, what are the reasons for this difference in treatment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. Where either or both of a married couple, because of illness or infinite basis and their living expenses are or are likely to be greater than they would otherwise be, each may receive single rate pension. Eligibility for single rate pension was extended to persons in this situation in 1970 in recognition that they have lost the normal financial advantages of cost sharing.

However, for income test purposes the combined income of the couple is still taken into account and the allowable income remains unchanged, although the level of income at which pension ceases to be payable is extended in keeping with payment of the single rate of pension. If each were treated as a single person for income test purposes the halving principle would not be applicable and overall disadvantage could result. It is only where a couple is living apart and estranged that they are treated as separate entities for pension income test purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How was the newest wheat parasite, striped rust, introduced into Australia.
(2) What is the economic significance of this new infestation and are there any steps which may be taken to further minimise the chance of arrival of similar diseases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry, in consultation with the Assistant Director-General (Plant Quarantine), Department of Health, has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to state precisely how the stripe rust of wheat reached Australia. The possibilities are:
on air currents
in association with seed
with cereal straw
in association with non plant items

Rusts are capable of reaching Australia on air currents as is strongly suspected to be the case with peanut rust. There is a wide global distribution for stripe rust but the strain detected in Australia is a European strain which virtually precludes arrival by air currents.

All cereal seed, including wheat, which is approved import into Australia undergoes a prescribed treatment before being grown for one generation in quarantine for observation. The prescribed hot water treatment of the seed is adequate to render non viable any rust spores associated with the seed.
Cereal straw is a prohibited import.
The spore of stripe rust is rather fragile, susceptible to sunlight and is not expected to remain viable for a long period on non host material.
The introduction of stripe rust was possibly associated with a person either as an illegal introduction of wheat seed or straw or with non host material.

(2) Experienced plant pathologists in Victoria have stated that stripe rust is expected to be regular crop disease in Victoria each season. Stripe rust is expected to reduce the 1980 yield in Victoria by one or two per cent according to officers in the Victorian Department of Agriculture. One variety has sustained losses as high as 25 per cent. Certain varieties have already shown resistance and it is likely that breeding for resistance will be the long term approach to control although spraying has been effective on varieties which are susceptible.

Immediately following the discovery of stripe rust in October 1979, a request was made to the Wheat Industry Research Council for a special supplementary grant of $150,000 to build a new glasshouse at the University of Sydney Castle Hill research site to facilitate reasearch into the disease. On the recommendation of the Council, the Minister for Primary Industry approved the allocation of the funds to the project out of session.
As part of the proposal the New South Wales Department of Agriculture agreed to make available an officer to work with University Staff. The glasshouse is currently under construction.

Two additional projects on stripe rust are being funded by the Council in its 1980-81 program. Every effort is being made to gather basic information on the disease so that control measures can be devised and information on resistant varieties passed on to growers at the earliest opportunity.

Quarantine can devise safe procedures for introductions but is dependent upon co-operation of the community to achieve success. In recent times quarantine has pursued a policy of higher penalties for quarantine offenders as a deterrent for illegal imports.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Energy Gain in Alternative Energy Sources

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the comparative energy gain in the production of various alternative energy sources such as: (a) oil-fired electricity; (b) coal-fired electricity; (c) ethanol; (d) shale oil; (e) methanol; and (f) synthetic oil from coal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The percentage of the input energy available as output energy-thermal efficiency-is conventionally used as the basis for comparing the production of various alternative energy sources.
(a) and (b) For electricity generation in large units at full load capacity, thermal efficiencies are
30-33 per cent for oil-fired gas turbines
40-42 per cent for diesel generators
32-37 per cent for oil for steam raising
28-33 per cent for brown coal
35-40 per cent for black coal.
(c), (d), (e) and (f) In the case of synthetic liquid fuels, thermal efficiencies are
34-44 per cent for ethanol, depending on the biomass feedstock used and the process technology
80-85 per cent for oil from shale, depending on the quality of shale, the process technology and the type of oil product
about 65 per cent for methanol production from natural gas and about 50 per cent from black coal
40-60 per cent for oil from coal, depending on the quality of coal, the process technology and the type of oil product.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

(2) Does one of the techniques of transcendental meditation consist of chanting mantras and the names of gods, and that TM proponents claim that transcendental meditation confers such supernatural powers as levitation.
(3) What is the relevance of such techniques to the medical conditions for which they may be prescribed and is there any scientifically acceptable proof of the efficacy of the treatment.

(4) Is the Minister satisfied that the payment of medical benefits for such controversial treatments is properly a matter for Government approvals; if so, will the Minister continue to give this approval.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Transcendental meditation (TM) is not listed as a medical service in the Medical Benefits Schedule. Because the reasons for a professional attendance by a general practitioner are normally not given, it is not possible to provide figures for the incidence or cost of such treatment.
(2) I do not consider it appropriate for me to comment on the general techniques of TM or on claims made by its proponents.

(3), (4) and (5) See (1). Medical benefits are attracted for consultations by legally qualified medical practitioners. It would be neither practical nor desirable to attempt in any form to restrict the way in which doctors choose to conduct their consultations. Medical benefits are not payable for TM treatment as such. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Entry into Australia by Religious Cults

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do any restrictions apply to applications for entry into Australia by leaders and officials of religious cults such as Ananda Marga, the Worldwide Unification Church, and the Church of Scientology.

(2) Are there any circumstances under which the Government will refuse entry to leaders and officials of religious cults convicted of offences relating to the misuse of funds, profiteering from religious fund-raising or misrepresentation in gaining concessions available to religious organisations.
(3) Are the normal restrictions concerning entry of persons with criminal convictions waived in the case of officials of a religious organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no special restrictions on the entry to Australia of members of specific religious cults. All applications for entry to Australia, whether on a temporary basis or for permanent residence are considered on their individual merits. A person seeking residence in Australia who intends to follow an occupation of ministering to the spiritual needs of the community may be approved if nominated by a religious body in Australia recognised for the purposes of the Marriage Act. Applicants must have undertaken a form of theological training recognised by the religious body and be engaged on duties proposed by the religious body. Full financial support for the religious nominee and for family members, if any, is to be given by the religious body.

Should a person who is a leader or official of a denomination and who is other than a person ministering to the spiritual needs of the community seek entry for residence each such case is decided on its merits.
All members of religious bodies seeking entry for residence must meet the normal requirements of health and character applicable to all migrants.
(2) and (3) Normal health and character are required and the results assessed on a case by case basis. Generally persons entering Australia are required to be of good character.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Sydney Home Nursing Service had to severely restrict its services to patients.
(2) Did the Government freeze staff levels in district nursing services in August 1976.
(3) Is this freeze still in force; if so, why do such restrictions apply to this vital form of domiciliary care which does so much for the housebound elderly and disabled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am informed that the Sydney Home Nursing Service has recently restricted services in some areas of the Sydney metropolitan area.

(2) Staff levels were not frozen as such, but the Commonwealth subsidy payable was limited to the number of nurses being subsidised in August 1976. However, the actual rate of subsidy per nurse has been increased each year consistent with changes in the salaries payable to nurses. Despite the limitation on the number of nurses subsidised by the Commonwealth, most of the major organisations have found it possible to increase the number of nurses employed since 1976.

(3) The limitation still applies. It was imposed as part of the overall effort to restrain Government expenditure. However, the Government has agreed to amend the Home Nursing Subsidy Scheme to, inter alia, remove the limitation and replace it with a cash ceiling determined in the Budget context each year. As the Home Nursing Subsidy Act provides that the Commonwealth subsidy cannot exceed the amount of State assistance, the proposed changes have been discussed with State authorities without, so far, agreement being reached. Discussions are continuing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Veterans' Affairs act as the agent for the British Department of Health and Social Security in war pension matters, whereas in the case of civilian pensioners the Department of Social Security is not the agent; if so: (a) what is the reason for these arrangements; and (b) were there consultations between the Australian and British authorities before such arrangements were made.

(2) Does the Department of Veterans' Affairs collect alleged overpayments at the request of the British Department of Health and Welfare; if so, what investigations does it make into individual cases before pursuing with the collection of such alleged overpayments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(a) To facilitate the payment of war compensation payments to British veterans and dependants resident in Australia, the Department of Veterans' Affairs acts as agent for the British Department of Health and Social Security whereby it pays pensions and/or allowances for British veterans and widows and provides treatment for service-related disabilities of British veterans.
(b) Yes.

(2) Yes. Overpayments not exceeding #50 (sterling) due to a payment error where the payee is at fault are recovered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs under the rules laid down by the United Kingdom Treasury. Overpayments exceeding #50 (sterling), or involving fraud or misrepresentation, or caused by an incorrect award, are referred to the Department of Health and Social Security in the United Kingdom, for appropriate instructions regarding the action to be taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: How many:
(a) patients in excluded wards of hospitals; and
(b) patients receiving temporary pensions in non-excluded wards of hospitals will become entitled to pension benefits following the passing of the Social Services Amendment Bill 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) From November 1980, patients in non-excluded wards of mental hospitals can qualify for the payment of social security pensions. It is estimated that some 1,400 patients in non-excluded wards of mental hospitals will become eligible for social security pensions or benefits.
Patients in excluded wards of mental hospitals were already able to qualify for pensions or sickness benefits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: What, if any, taxation concessions are available for Australian citizens who serve at Antarctic bases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Macquarie Island, the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Island and the Australian Antarctic Territory are within income tax Zone A. Consequently, Australian citizens who have resided in or actually been in one or more of those areas for more than one half of a year of income are entitled to the appropriate zone allowance. The present basic allowance for Zone A is a rebate of $216. It is higher when the taxpayer concerned has dependents.

In relation to sales tax, goods taken to the Antarctic mainland, Heard Island and McDonald Island by Australian citizens are regarded as goods exported and are exempt from tax. Macquarie Island is a part of Tasmania and goods taken there are not regarded as being exported. Exemption, therefore, does not apply to such goods.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) From what manned light-stations in Queensland does the Meteorological Bureau receive daily or more frequent weather reports.
(2) What use is made of these reports in compiling weather reports, including cyclone warnings and what is the cost to the Meteorological Bureau of receiving these reports.
(3) What steps is the Bureau taking to ensure continuation of these reports after the demanning of light-stations and what will be the cost of such arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Bureau of Meteorology receives weather reports daily from the manned Queensland light-stations at Bustard Head, Cape Capricorn, Cape Cleveland, Cape Moreton, Double Island Point, Fitzroy Island, Lady Elliot Island, Low Isles, Pine Islet and Sandy Cape. Special emergency observations are made on request at Booby and Dent Islands for tropical cyclone warning purposes.
(2) (a) Weather reports from the manned Queensland coastal lights:
(i) are sometimes vital for tropical cyclone warning purposes. The Bureau's Warning Centre at Brisbane sometimes requires more frequent reports from the regularly reporting stations
(ii) are an important part of the general observing network and very valuable for meteorological analysis, forecasting and warning, in particular for coastal regions of Queensland and adjacent waters
(iii) are broadcast by coastal radio stations at Brisbane, Rockhampton and Thursday Island and by some ABC and commercial radio stations.

(b) In the 1979-80 financial year weather reports from the manned Queensland lighthouses cost the Bureau of Meteorology approximately $160,000 consisting of about $107,000 paid in allowances, and nearly $53,000 for telegrams.
(3) (a) When demanning of particular lighthouses is proposed the Bureau consults with the Department of Transport and also
(i) investigates the possibility of obtaining alternative co-operative observers in the vicinity

(ii) considers the installation of automatic weather stations where co-operative observers cannot be obtained and investigates other network arrangements which would reduce the impact of the loss of observations of sea conditions, cloud, visibility and weather phenomena which are difficult and expensive to observe with automatic stations.

(b) The Bureau of Meteorology plans to install an automatic weather station on Lady Elliot Island in the first half of 1981. Other installations at the weather reporting lighthouses on the Queensland coast, except Dent Island, will follow if no alternative manned weather reporting stations can be established by the time that they are automated.

(c) An automatic weather station capable of reporting wind speed and direction, rainfall, pressure, air temperature and humidity and reporting by telex, costs in the vicinity of $15,000 installed, with an annual recurring cost (inclusive of depreciation, communications charges and maintenance) of about $4,000.
(d) The Bureau already uses automatic weather stations successfully including ten on the Queensland coast and adjacent islands.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the criteria used to determine the amount of Vitamin C supplement which will attract additional funds under the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act.
(2) Are these criteria made available to local government and voluntary organisations which receive funding, in a departmental document.
(3) How often are inspections made to ascertain whether the Vitamin C supplement is of the appropriate quality.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The criteria used to approve Vitamin C supplements are:
(a) that the item is sufficiently rich in Vitamin C;
(b) that it can conveniently be delivered with or incorporated into delivered meals;
(c) that it is acceptable to elderly people in the quantities required.

Following consultation with the Nutrition and Dietetics Division of the University of New South Wales and with the Nutrition Section of the Commonwealth Department of Health, a schedule of Vitamin C supplements have been approved and incorporated in the application form for subsidy.

The items listed on the form represent the alternatives which may be provided in order to offer a choice of preferred items to recipients. If any organisation wishing to provide a Vitamin C supplement encounters difficulty in obtaining the fruits or fruit juices listed in the schedule, due to seasonal or other factors, my Department will consider in consultation with expert authorities approving substitute sources of Vitamin C.
(3) My Department aims to inspect each delivered meals service on an annual basis, but given the wide distribution of services this is not always possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a statement from a senior official of the oil industry recently indicate that despite the actions of the Federal Government, which has brought about a certain degree of conservation of fuel, there would be a continuing fall-off in fuel production, particularly as the Bass Strait output dwindles.

(2) Did the report further state that it appeared the only feasible means of overcoming future shortages was to encourage the production of alternative fuels such as shale oil and synthetic fuel from plants.
(3) What is the present situation in safeguarding future energy requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Various press reports appeared of statements made by Mr J. Kirk, Chairman and Managing Director of Esso Australia Ltd, when releasing his company's report 'Australian Energy Outlook'. I assume it is these reports which are referred to in the question. The Government has been aware that Bass Strait oil is a finite resource and as such its production can be expected to decline in the future.

(2) In the discussion on Australia's energy future the report covered several means of overcoming possible future oil supply shortages. These included exploration, conservation and subsitution as well as the development of synthetic fuels.

(3) There have been a number of statements to Parliament and elsewhere outlining the Government's approach to safeguarding Australia's future energy requirements the most recent of which is the Prime Minister's statement made in August 1980 'Energy Policy and Related Resource Development'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people are currently receiving training under the National Employment and Training (NEAT) Scheme.
(2) How many of these are (a) women; and (b) women born outside Australia; and (c) Aboriginals.

(2) Of these there were (a) a total of 10,154 women in training, (b) of these 1,368 were born outside Australia, and (c) 2,800 Aboriginal persons were in training.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people are currently receiving training under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training (CRAFT) Scheme.
(2) How many of these are women.
(3) How many of these are women born outside Australia.
(4) How many are Aboriginals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated size of the Aboriginal work force in Australia.
(2) What is the total number of unemployed Aboriginal (a) men; and (b) women.
(3) What is the total number of unemployed Aboriginals in the 15 to 19 years age group.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: How many non-Aboriginal Australians are without access to:
(a) telephones on the standard Telephone network;
(b) telephones on the standard Telecom network or radio telephones;
(c) telephones on the standard Telecom network, radio telephones or two-way radio; and
(d) any kind of telephone or radio communications.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: For the purposes of this question, the term 'standard Telecom' is taken to apply to all telephone services for which Telecom Australia charges a rental fee, and includes telephone services which depend on some form of radio for their connection to a telephone exchange. On this basis, the answers to the question are:
(a) and (b) Recent demographic studies of outback areas show that approximately 15,000 non-Aboriginal Australians are at present in areas without access to telephones.

(c) Approximately 14,600 non-Aboriginal Australians are at present without access to telephones on the standard Telecom network, radio telephones or two-way radio. The difference between (a) and (c) arises from the trial connection of approximately 60 outpost radio stations to the Telecom network at Cairns and Darwin.

(d) In all areas without access to the telephone network it is usually possible to obtain access by outpost radio to services such as those operated by the Royal Flying Doctor Service. It is not known how many people in these areas have not availed themselves of this facility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1980 (Hansard, pages 32, 33) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning a proposed low energy hospital in Britain.
