The concept of a low energy hospital is a most interesting one and I have arranged that my Department obtain information on the project.
Once this material is received, it will be distributed to all State and Territory health authorities having responsibility for the construction of hospitals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1980 (Hansard, page 34) Senator MacGibbon asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Government propose to allow the Special Broadcasting Service to accept limited sponsorship of programs on Channel 0/28? Will the Government be faced with additional outlays with respect to this service which were not foreseen in the Budget Estimates?
The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

My Department has received legal advice on Section 79ZA (d) of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, which relates to program sponsorship. I understand that the terms of the provision do not enable me to approve the sorts of program sponsorship which would generate sufficient revenue to have a significant impact on the Special Broadcasting Service's budget.
The 1980-81 budget appropriation was based on a certain level of advertising revenue which cannot now be achieved and the Special Broadcasting Service may require additional funds.
The usual reviews of budget appropriations are due early in the new year and the level of additional funding required by the Special Broadcasting Service will be assessed as part of that process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, page 105) Senator Puplick asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: If the Northern Territory Government proceeds unilaterally to the establishment of a university-clearly not needed in Australia at this stage-will it be made clear to the Northern Territory Government that it will be its exclusive responsibility to pay all of the costs of this establishment and that funds will not be provided by the Commonwealth's diverting funds from existing tertiary institutions?
The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Northern Territory Government has been advised on a number of occasions that the Commonwealth Government would give no indication of support or commitment to provide funds for the establishment of a university in Darwin in advance of a formal proposal being examined by the Tertiary Education Commission, and the Government considering the Commission's advice. It has been emphasised that the Northern Territory Government should not anticipate that a favourable decision will necessarily follow the Commission's review.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Entry of Medibank Private in Telephone Directory

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, page 108) and 2 December 1980 (Hansard, page 210), Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the listings of Medibank Private and the Health Insurance Commission in telephone directories.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Health Insurance Commission is a Commonwealth Statutory Authority established under the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 to provide, through Medibank Private, health insurance to the people of Australia.
I and my Department regard Medibank Private in the same way as other private medical and hospital benefits funds which operate as registered organizations under the National Health Act.

However, unlike Trans-Australia Airlines, the Health Insurance Commission did perform a Government function until the legislative changes introduced on 1 November 1978 which abolished Medibank Standard.

Since that date the Commission has taken steps to correct its entries in the telephone directories and for example 6 of the 7 capital city directories for 1980 showed Medibank Private in the non-Government section although in some cases Telecom elected to insert a cross reference. I understand this is standard practice after an important change on at least the first reprint of the directory.

The Health Insurance Commission has written to Telecom asking that future entries in all telephone directories, including country ones, should show Medibank Private in the general section of the directories only.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, pages 107-8) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning Government assistance to diabetics in meeting the cost of insulin syringes and needles.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
Consideration has been given to ways and means by which Government assistance can be given to diabetics to help in meeting the cost of insulin syringes and needles.

The Government is sympathetic to the needs of diabetics and is mindful of the costs to the patient in the management of diabetes. However, in the current economic situation, which has necessitated policies of restraint in public expenditure, it has not been possible for the Government to commit itself to additional programs, such as assistance with the cost of insulin syringes and needles. Nevertheless this matter will be kept under review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1980 (Hansard, page 209) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the safety standards of sunbeds imported from Europe.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am not aware of any specific safety standards which apply to this type of equipment. However the possible health hazards including skin and eye damage associated with the use of artificial sun tanning systems are currently being investigated by the National Health and Medical Research Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1980 (Hansard, page 207) Senator Robertson asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. The question concerned the proposed withdrawal of RAN Tracker aircraft from Darwin.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In a joint press release dated 24 November 1980, the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Transport announced that the three RAN Tracker aircraft which had been conducting aerial surveillance off the north and north-west coast of Australia since November 1977 were planned to be withdrawn from Darwin in mid-December 1980, subject to the successful completion of evaluation trials by radar-equipped Nomad aircraft under charter to the Department of Transport. The Nomad aircraft have been assessed as suitable for the task and the RAN Tracker aircraft were withdrawn from Darwin on 12 December 1980.

The current arrangements for civil coastal surveillance were introduced by the Government in 1978 following a review of surveillance requirements. Under these arrangements the Minister for Transport is the Government spokesman on civil surveillance matters and co-ordinates the activities of the combination of Defence and civil assets employed on civil coastal surveillance operations. Civil aircraft under charter to the Department of Transport conduct daily air searches of the coast from Karratha to Cairns, RAAF aircraft fly up to 2,500 hours each year patrolling the 200 nm Australian Fishing Zone and nine RAN patrol boats are made available for civil coastal surveillance, response and enforcement operations.

In announcing the new arrangements to operate from 1978, the Government stated that they would be the subject of a major review. That review, which is scheduled to be presented to Government in mid-1981, is to be a comprehensive assessment enabling firm judgments to be made about the effectiveness of existing arrangements and decisions to be taken on future arrangements for the conduct of civil coastal surveillance. I am advised that the Minister for Transport intends to make a statement to the press shortly concerning that review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 270) Senator Archer asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications ascertain whether any decision to extend national radio broadcasting to areas on the West Coast of Tasmania has been made? Has any assessment been made of the possibility of shared national-commercial translator facilities to that locality? In view of the isolation of the people working in this area, can any measures be taken to speed up the program to improve reception?
The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

My Department and I are aware of the radio reception difficulties experienced by residents throughout the West Coast of Tasmania. As the initial step towards final solution of this matter, my Department has completed field investigations in the area and a draft planning proposal incorporating recommendations for the establishment of commercial broadcasting translator stations, at a number of locations in the area, is currently being prepared. These locations are:
(i) Rosebery-Renison Bell
(ii) Savage River-Luina
(iii) Waratah
(iv) Strahan
(v) Zeehan

Following the established procedure of consultation with industry bodies and other interested parties, it is expected that the proposal will be submitted to me for consideration during the first quarter of 1981.

With regard to the establishment of national broadcasting services in the area, a submission is currently being prepared by the National Broadcasting Service Planning Committee. This submission will assess the possibility of shared national/ commercial translator facilities at the above localities and is expected to be provided to me for consideration during the first quarter of 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 263) Senator Button asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Government yet know precisely what services will be offered to rural householders by the proposed domestic satellite system and at what cost to the householder? If not, when will the Government know this? When will it make a clear statement to end the confusion over this issue?
The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
On 18 September 1980 the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications announced the Government's decision to issue a Request for Tender for the National Communications Satellite System.
The most important aspect of this decision is the Government's commitment to establish a system which would facilitate the provision of:
(i) a range of services for those who have none;
(ii) improvements for those with poor services; and
(iii) a wider range of services for those with only a few.
It is intended that the following services will be available to rural householders as a result of the introduction of the satellite system:
(i) reception of radio and television programs;
(ii) an automatic telephony service, with the option of other telecommunications services such as telex, facsimili etc; and,
(iii) improved communications for School of the Air Services.
The capacity and design of the system is such as to permit the introduction of other services. These will be introduced as user demand for specific services develop.

On the matter of cost to the householder, one of the major purposes of the Request for Tender to which interested firms are now preparing responses is to seek firm prices for the satellite system, including earth station equipment to be used by individual householders.

Only after the receipt of tenders for the space and earth segments of the satellite system and their subsequent analysis will the Government be in a position to assess total system costs and the cost to the householders for particular services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 268) Senator Melzer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the toxic shock syndrome and the use of tampons.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The matter of tampons and toxic shock syndrome was considered by the Public Health Advisory Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) on 13 and 14 October 1980, and by the NH & MRC itself on 30 and 31 October 1980. Items are included on the agenda of these bodies together with appropriate background material and the public health aspects of such items are then discussed. No specific terms of reference are provided for each individual item on the agenda.

The Australian Government Analytical Laboratory in Sydney was requested to examine samples of tampons supplied from all States and the Northern Territory for the presence of carboxy-methyl-cellulose. An analysis for this substance in super absorbent sanitary napkins has also been requested.

The detailed proceedings of the NH & MRC, its Committees and Subcommittees are confidential. I do not believe that any useful purpose would be served by making public the deliberations of Committees and Subcommittees which necessarily report to the NH & MRC and whose proposals are therefore subject to review.

Indeed, the reports of the NH & MRC and its advisory Committees are not verbatim records, but summaries of the main points of discussion and necessary action. However, clearly worded statements summarising NH & MRC discussions are published, as was done in relation to toxic shock syndrome immediately after the recent Session in October 1980.
The data, on which the discussions were based in both the Advisory Committee and the NH & MRC, are available to the public in the following publications:
The USA Centre for Disease Control's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (CDC/MMWR)-issues of
19 September 1980
17 October 1980
CDC/MMWR summary
1 October 1980
USA Food and Drug Administration (FDA) publications:
Talk Paper 3 October 1980
News Release 25 September 1980
British Medical Journal (Editorial)
1 November 1980.

Editorial comments in my Department's publication Communicable Diseases Intelligence (CDI) of 15 August 1980 and 5 December 1980 stated that 'the CDI would be interested in receiving information on any Australian cases of this newly recognised illness'. The syndrome, including discussion of symptoms, was covered comprehensively in both of these issues, but was first described in considerable clinical detail in the issue of 20 June 1980, before association of this condition with tampon usage had been highlighted.

Copies of the relevant issues of the CDI publications, in which the form of words soliciting information and the description of symptoms were given, have been placed in the Parliamentary library, where the honourable senator may check the precise wording.
Finally, no direction has been given within my Department that queries concerning tampons or other related matters are to be recorded and sent in a memorandum to the Director-General.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December 1980 (Hansard, page 341) Senator Melzer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice querying why it was not possible to use pharmaceutical benefit records to identify women for whom the drug diethylstilboestrol has been prescribed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

Pharmaceutical benefit records only include data on items supplied as benefits under the National Health Act. Specifically excluded are data on items prescribed in hospitals covered by Commonwealth/State cost-sharing arrangements, as well as private prescriptions for items which may or may not be available as pharmaceutical benefits; also benefit items for persons not holding a current Pensioner Health Benefit card, where the dispensed price is equal to or less than the patient contribution (currently $2.75). Two of the four strengths of DES currently available as pharmaceutical benefits fall within this latter category.

As the pharmaceutical benefits processing system is primarily concerned with the reimbursement of pharmaceutical chemists for dispensing undertaken under the provisions of the National Health Act, patient identification is not included in computer-held records. In addition, prescription forms are only retained by my Department for three years, after which they are destroyed in accordance with Finance Direction Section 34/10. Manual searching through about 300 million prescriptions processed during the immediate three year period is seen as being impractical. Even if this were to be considered, subsequent follow-up action with those prescribers willing to co-operate would be necessary to determine-
(a) sex of the patient (in some instances);
(b) patient's condition at the time of treatment; and
(c) current address of patient.

However, a further consideration which would arise at this juncture would be the provisions of section 135A of the National Health Act concerning the non-disclosure of information obtained under the Act. On this basis, I propose to await further advice from the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee as indicated in my letter to the honourable senator dated 23 October 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December 1980 (Hansard, page 343) Senator O'Byrne asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the declaration of pecuniary interests of doctors in private hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Government's involvement in the private hospital sector is limited to approving premises as a hospital under the Health Insurance Act, for the purpose of payment of the Commonwealth's daily bed subsidy. The Act does not give a great deal of discretion in such approvals, requiring that premises be approved if they are 'fitted, furnished, and staffed' appropriately for operation as a hospital. The Act does not give discretion in terms of denying approval on the basis of who owns the premises. The Act uses the term 'proprietor', who of course may or may not be the owner of the hospital.

No investigation into investment in hospitals by members of the medical profession has been undertaken by my Department as there is no statutory basis for doing so. Nor is there any statutory basis for the establishment of a register of pecuniary interests of doctors.

I do not consider it appropriate at this late stage to specifically refer this matter to the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. Firstly, the terms of reference for the Commission are broad enough to allow consideration of the question of ownership of hospitals and, if the matter is regarded by the Commission as significant, I expect it will be canvassed in the Commission's Report. TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 443) Senator MacGibbon asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. His question concerned the Government's deferral of the decision on selection of the new tactical fighter and whether the Government would consider purchase of Phantom aircraft as a stopgap measure for the next eight years.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Minister for Defence has advised that in the 1976 Defence White Paper the Government announced it had decided to proceed with project development for the acquisition of the new tactical fighter. The only deferral in this project since then was the announcement made by the Minister for Defence on 4 December 1980.

In that statement to Parliament, the Minister said the Government regretted the necessity to defer selection of the new tactical fighter. The decision was made on the basis of advice from the Government's most senior professional military and civilian defence advisers.

I am advised that the fundamental issue here is not that a time-table for decision which appeared realistic a year ago be adhered to, but rather that the Government should have at its disposal all the information necessary to make a considered judgement. To make a decision in our present circumstances of incomplete knowledge of the likely future development of both aircraft would be a gross irresponsibility.

The Government expects additional information on both aircraft to become available around mid-1981 to enable further evaluation of the contenders. The Government will make a decision on selection as soon as possible thereafter.
I am advised that purchase of Phantom aircraft as an interim fighter would be wasteful of defence resources in our present and foreseeable strategic circumstances.

A life extension program for the Mirage fleet is presently in progress. This will enable the RAAF to maintain flying and air combat skills and provide the country with an adequate air defence capability in the period up to the entry into service of the new tactical fighter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 440) Senator Rae asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology in the Senate. The question concerned metric conversion.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

State legislation has always controlled trading practices in regard to weights and measures, and pricing. Prior to 1970 that legislation required the sole use of the imperial system. As a consequence of the conversion program, all States introduced transitional provisions permitting both systems of measurement to be used whilst the measuring devices were being changed.

In most States that transitional phase was completed by end 1977 after which only sole metric practice was permitted but in Queensland and Western Australia the difficulties of conversion in remote areas have delayed the termination of imperial usage till now. Good trading practice, and consumer protection require that goods be priced in terms of the unit in which they will be actually measured.

Regulations have been in force for two years to control the import of non-metric measuring instruments. They were intended to assist the completion of conversion of particular sector programs and have been effective in that aim. They were also designed to protect the consumer from goods which would have a very limited life as the conversion proceeded rapidly to its conclusion. However recognising that conversion would, of necessity, proceed slowly in areas such as precision engineering, adequate provision was made for imperial measuring devices to be available to those sectors. Reports in the newspapers that certain rulers would have to be destroyed or re-exported arose from a misunderstanding which has since been corrected.

Metric conversion has been a major cultural change similar to, but much greater in impact than, currency conversion. In that former conversion, there was no question of freedom of choice: The old currency was withdrawn after a two-year transition period and ceased to be legal. Metric conversion, because of its complexity and for practical consideration, has taken much longer and in some areas will require many years yet. Nevertheless it is in everyone's interest to complete the change as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Telecom Australia and Australian Postal Commission: Profits

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 435) Senator Elstob asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: When will the Australian people get the benefits of the profits of Telecom Australia and the Australian Postal Commission by way of cheaper and more efficient telephone and postal services.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In referring to the profits generated by both the Postal and Telecommunications Commissions, it is necessary to bear in mind that each Commission was set up basically to operate as a trading enterprise.
The annual profits (or trading surpluses) retained by the Commissions have been used as a source of financing the capital expenditures required to maintain and extend the respective service networks.

In the case of Telecom the capital expenditure program has enabled the Commission to upgrade rural telephone services and to provide services to new subscribers in areas close to capital cities where urban development is taking place and any other areas of population growth without significant delays.

The Commission has avoided increasing the level of local telephone charges for some years and has taken a number of significant initiatives to reduce STD telephone rates, including the introduction of Community Access 80 in May last year.
In other service areas where financial considerations permit there have also been tariff reductions such as the lowering of the long distance telex charges from 1 July 1980.

Australia Post has utilised part of its trading surpluses to fund its annual capital programs, including projects for the decentralisation of mail network centres. The increased efficiency of the decentralised network scheme will be of considerable benefit to users of the mail service.
If the Commission had not generated these profits the programs outlined above may well have had to be financed by the tax-paying public at large rather than by the users of the services.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1980 (Hansard, page 31) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning the capacity of engineering departments in universities and colleges of advanced education to meet further demands for engineers. Honourable Senators may recall that during this period, there were public statements by professional and industrial groups that a surplus of engineers was developing.

Interest amongst students in engineering courses has, however, risen again and increased demand for places in engineering schools in 1980 and 1981 should result in the output of graduate engineers returning to at least current levels by 1983 or 1984.
I understand that the Tertiary Education Commission will be commenting on this matter in Volume 1 of its report to the Government for the 1982-1984 triennium which will be available shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1980 (Hansard, page 33) Senator Bishop asked me a question without notice concerning air fares on the domestic component of international travel to and from South Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, page 106) Senator Lajovic asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister noted an item in the interim annual report of 1979-80 of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation stating that the Corporation has undertaken to supply the proposed newsprint mill with water and that work has commenced on augmentation of the system? Can the Minister inform the Senate firstly, what will be the total cost to the taxpayer of this service to the mill; secondly, what will be the effect on the environment of the area; and thirdly, what will be the cost and supply effect of the new extension of this service to the mill to the traditional users of water in that area?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) The water supply to the Albury Mill of Australian Newsprint Mills (ANM) forms part of the total water supply system to the new city of Thurgoona. The proportion of cost attributable to the mill is $3.28 million which will be financed by the Corporation from its own resources. This amount includes expenditure of $0.9 million by the Corporation this year. The company has entered into a 35 year agreement, whereby it will repay the total amount spent by the Corporation plus interest by way of a fixed monthly charge, which will ensure full recovery of the Corporation's costs.

(2) The company has produced an environment impact statement which has been on public display and has been submitted, in accordance with environmental legislation requirements, to the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian Governments. It was also submitted to the South Australian Government for information. Licences to operate the mill provide for the maintenance of environmental standards in accordance with New South Wales Pollution Control Legislation.

(3) The augmentation works referred to in the question provide for pumping of raw water from the Murray River direct to the mill. This ensures that the existing filtered water supply for domestic purposes is separated from the raw water supply. The separation works are in the category of 'further works' the cost of which will be added to the amount set out in (1) above and will be repaid by the company under the terms of the Agreement mentioned above. The mill's water supply will be a direct service which will in no way affect the traditional users of water in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 263) Senator Lewis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has he seen a report of the employment officer at Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd at Port Kembla that he is rejecting each year 1,000 or more would-be apprentices because they are unable to pass a basic numeracy test, that his results show that 70 per cent of the applicants obtain less than 50 per cent of the marks and that 50 per cent of the applicants cannot even score a 20 per cent mark. Does the Minister agree that industry throughout Australia is having trouble obtaining suitable applicants for apprenticeships due to their weaknesses in both mathematics and English? Is there a fundamental weakness in mathematics in our primary school teachers, in that no mathematics qualification is necessary for a primary school teacher? Will the Government give consideration to arranging with industry for government and industry to speak with headmasters and school councillors to make sure that they are properly briefed on the basic academic requirements for apprenticeship? Will the Government give consideration to publicising the better job opportunities which are available in Australia to those students who persevere with the hard core mathematics and English during their secondary education, rather than the limited opportunities available to those who select soft options?
The Minister for Education has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

I am aware of the comments made by the employment officer at Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd concerning apprenticeship testing. The situation he reports is indeed a matter of concern. Without a more detailed knowledge of the test administered, however, and an indication both of its relationship to the mathematics curriculum in schools and of its validity for the purposes of apprenticeship selection, I am not in a position to make any substantive comment on this specific case.

I am able to offer some general observations on the basic skills levels reached by school leavers, a matter which in recent years has come under close scrutiny by Australian educators. It is relevant to note in this context that the Australian Education Council is currently investigating nationally the basic skills levels reached by 10 and 14 year-olds. The evidence from recent studies is that there has been no significant decline in basic skills when the school population is taken as a whole, although a minority of students leave school with some deficiencies in the basic skills of literacy and numeracy. It is probable, as a result of the massive increase in the proportion of students remaining to Year 10, that the range of abilities of students applying for entry to skilled trade training is now much greater than was the case some years ago, and this could be reflected in the selection test scores of applicants for apprenticeships. This may present some problems during the selection process, but the fact is that the number of new apprenticeship indentures registered annually has increased considerably over the last five years.

A further question concerns the mathematics ability of primary school teachers. There has been evidence presented in the Report of the National Inquiry into Teacher Education, for example, that 72 per cent of Victorian entrants into primary teacher training in the last three years had taken no mathematics at Year 12 level. Other State reports on teacher education expressed a similar concern for the level of proficiency in mathematics of their recruits for teaching. Many teacher education students take advantage of bridging courses offered by tertiary institutions to improve their levels of proficiency in mathematics and the Report of the National Inquiry underlines the responsibility of institutions to ensure that graduates of teacher education programs at all levels have reached adequate standards in the areas of language and mathematics.

On the question of consultation between industry and schools regarding academic requirements for apprenticeship, this is essentially a matter for the education systems and schools in the States to take up. The basic academic requirements for entry to apprenticeship in terms of attainment in school courses are laid down by apprenticeship authorities in each State and territory and these requirements would generally be well known to counsellors advising students who are seeking apprenticeships. On the more general level, the Commonwealth Government is of course concerned that young people should have as much relevant information as possible about employers' requirements. Under the Transition from School to Work Program, State and non-Government education authorities are being assisted to improve their career, education and guidance services and some authorities are using funds to develop closer links with industry. In addition, the Commonwealth and the States are cooperating in a review of vocational guidance services as part of the transition program. This is an area therefore in which improvements are being effected.

Concerning the study of 'hard core mathematics and English', there has been considerable public comment on a recent Victorian report purporting to show that senior secondary students are deserting the more demanding subjects and courses in favour of easier options. At the national level, and at least where mathematics is concerned, a somewhat different picture emerges from a recent ACER study on secondary mathematics in Australia during the period 1964-1978. This shows that, consistent with the rise generally in retention rates through to the end of secondary schooling there was a considerable increase between 1964 and 1978 in the absolute numbers of students taking some mathematics in Year 12. There was also an increase in the number of students taking Year 12 mathematics courses leading to subsequent specialised studies involving mathematics. The overall proportion of Year 12 students taking some mathematics has remained fairly constant between 1964 and 1978, with an Australian average of about 60 per cent on both occasions, although the proportion of Year 12 students taking courses leading to subsequent specialised studies involving mathematics was lower in 1978 than in 1964. It is relevant also that the level of performance of Year 12 students in mathematics was a little higher in 1978 than was the case in 1964. In general, I consider that the education authorities in Australia are aware of the need to encourage students, particularly those who demonstrate the ability to pursue studies beyond secondary level, to persevere with subjects such as mathematics and English at senior level even though they may no longer be compulsory subjects for matriculation purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 269) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, a question without notice regarding the basis for determining freight charges between Tasmania and Victoria and the steps taken by the Government or the Australian National Line to stabilise freight costs across Bass Strait.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter falls more properly within the portfolio of the Minister for Transport and in my capacity as Minister representing that Minister I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANL, which is one of the major ship operators, has its freight rates approved by the Minister for Transport. The Honourable Senator will recall when TFES was introduced in 1976 it was an associated requirement that shipowners charge an economic freight rate. ANL's rates were immediately significantly increased. Further increases have been approved under the Australian Shipping Commission Act whenever justified by increased costs together with the obligation on ANL to meet a coastal dividend target approved by the Minister for Transport (and set at 18 per cent before tax for the current year).
With regard to the other major operator, Union Steamship, there is no legislation that requires ministerial approval of its freight rates but I understand that they are competitive with ANL.

Similarly freight forwarders' charges are not subject to ministerial approval under legislation. As you might know their charges are an aggregation of charges, of which the linehaul charge of the shipowner is only one part.

The Honourable Senator will recall that in 1971 a Senate standing committee determined that freight increases implemented by ANL in the previous year were fully justified. Subsequently their rates have been examined and increased and there is no reason to believe that the level of existing Bass Strait freight rates is not appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December 1980 (Hansard, page 334) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning comments in the 1979-80 Annual Report of the Australian Broadcasting Commission concerning staffing and financial matters.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The honourable senator referred in his questions to comments in the 1979-80 Annual Report of the Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC) concerning staffing and financial matters.

I can confirm that on 20 September 1980 the ABC did write to the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications, Mr Staley, expressing views on its statutory responsibility in relation to staffing matters similar to those set out in its recent Annual Report. Following receipt of this letter, members of the Government met with representatives of the ABC to discuss these matters, and the views of the Commission have been considered in detail by relevant Government Departments, in consultation with the ABC. The ABC Committee of Review has been appointed by the Government to review present and future services of the ABC, its policies, organisational structure, and performance. It is expected that the Committee will make recommendations on the issues of staffing and finance raised in the ABC Annual Report, and I can assure honourable senators that the Government will give proper consideration to these matters upon receipt of the report of the Committe of Review.

The Government is firmly of the opinion that financial allocations to the ABC should be considered within the context of the Government's overall economic strategy. Allocations to the ABC over the last five years have been provided in difficult economic circumstances during which the Government has been required to exercise a degree of financial restraint.

The Government has, nevetheless, been responsive to the special needs of the ABC. The 1980-81 Budget allocation to the ABC of $177.6 million comprised an increase of some 11 per cent over the appropriation for 1979-80. In the five year period 1975-76 to 1980-81, allocations to the ABC have increased from some $137.1 million to $177.6 million an increase of 29.5 per cent. In addition, the Government has given the ABC authority to generate revenue from entrepreneurial activities.

In all the circumstances, I believe that the level of funding provided to the ABC in this period has demonstrated the Government's determination to maintain an effective and efficient national broadcasting sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 439) Senator Townley asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, relates to the price of aviation spirit for light aircraft which no doubt the Minister is aware costs considerably more than fuel for a car. Is the Minister aware that due to this higher price of aviation spirit for light aircraft and consequently the cost of flying, many people who would otherwise choose flying as a career are being prohibited from doing so? TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 437) Senator Button asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Firstly, I remind him that there have been at least three major reviews of the Australian broadcasting system since the Fraser Government came to power. I refer to comments made yesterday by the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, in the House of Representatives and afterwards. Will the newly foreshadowed and fourth review of the Australian broadcasting system to be conducted by the Fraser Government-according to the Minister, that review will be completed by February next year and will examine amongst other things the public interest provisions of the broadcasting legislation-be in any sense open to members of the public so that they can make submissions about important public interest questions or will it be a closed departmental review? The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Submissions were invited from radio and television licensees, advertisers, film and television producers and distributors, unions, public interest groups and other interested persons, on the following issues:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Turbojet aircraft have never been completely prohibited from operating during the curfew. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Was hardship to Brisbane residents resulting from the late flights considered when it was determined that 'exceptional passenger hardship' existed (see Question No. 3129, Senate Hansard, p. 1421, dated 18 September 1980); if so, why was the hardship to Brisbane residents not the prime consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Both the interests of the residents and the interests of the passengers are taken into account when approval to operate during the curfew is considered. The degree of hardship to the residents, which consists primarily of annoyance and sleep arousal, is considered. The following factors are taken into account, whether the aircraft is arriving or departing (departing aircraft cause more annoyance than landing aircraft); the time of the proposed flight (flights before midnight cause less annoyance than flights at, say, 3 a.m.); the type of aircraft (some aircraft types are noisier than others); and the available runway (operations on some runway cause less annoyance than operations on other runways).

The circumstances surrounding the plight of the passengers are also considered. For example, the number of passengers, the availability of accommodation should the request be refused, the reason for the delay (industrial action, mechanical problems, weather etc.) and any alternative action available to the airlines.

Of the sixteen flights that operated during the period 1 March 1980 to 31 July 1980, all occurred before midnight, all six departing aircraft departed into the north-east over Moreton Bay and all but two of the arriving aircraft landed over Moreton Bay, ten of the delays were associated with industrial action and the remainder with adverse weather conditions. In these circumstances proper consideration was given the residents of Brisbane.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are personnel who served for six months or more on Rottnest Island between 3 September 1939 and 5 May 1944 deemed to have served in a theatre of war, and are they eligible for ex-service benefits.

(2) Are some of the these benefits denied to Royal Australian Air Force members who operated aircraft out of Darwin to islands off the Australian coast during that same period; if so, what is the rationale for this apparent anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For a person to be eligible to receive a Service pension, which is similar to the age and invalid pensions paid by the Department of Social Security and which is subject broadly to the same income test, he must have served in a theatre of war or, in the case of a female, served in a theatre of war, served abroad or embarked for service abroad.
Service in a theatre of war is defined in section 23 of the Repatriation Act 1920 as follows-

'' 'Served in a theatre of war' means served at sea, in the field or in the air, in naval, military or aerial operations against the enemy in an area, or on an aircraft or ship of war, at a time when danger from hostile forces of the enemy was incurred in that area or on that aircraft or ship of war by the person so serving''.

The Repatriation Commission has established certain guidelines, which relate in essence to recorded enemy activity in and around certain areas, for the application of this definition. In respect of service on Rottnest Island, the requirement is that a veteran must have served for a continuous period of not less than 3 months on the island between 3 September 1939 and 4 May 1944.
(2) Airmen who operated aircraft out of Darwin to islands contiguous to the coast, will be deemed to have served in a theatre of war if-
(i) between 3 September 1939 and 3 September 1945 they served in an aircraft which engaged in operations against the enemy or on reconnaissance or patrol duty over enemy occupied territory; or

(ii) between 19 February 1942 and 12 November 1943 they served for a continuous period of not less than three months in the Northern Territory north of parallel 14.5* south latitude or any of the islands contiguous to that part of the Northern Territory; or
(iii) at any time during the war they incurred actual danger from hostile forces.

If they served in an aircraft which did not engage in operations against the enemy or in reconnaissance or patrol duty over enemy occupied territory, they would not qualify under the first provision above.

Although it is recorded that islands such as Bathurst and Melville were attacked by Japanese aircraft on their way to the first bombing raid on Darwin on 19 February 1942 and that one or two Japanese aircraft were either shot down or crash landed on the islands, the islands were not enemy occupied. Therefore reconnaissance flights over the islands could not be considered as patrols over enemy occupied territory.

In setting down guidelines, it is recognised that it is not possible to cover every possible situation that may arise. However, this does not automatically preclude from entitlement to benefits any person whose service does not come within the guidelines. All such cases are considered on their individual merits.

In the Navy area, particularly in dockyards which operate within the general waterfront industrial environment disputation features regularly and is the cause of deep concern. In that area alone there could be some 30 industrial organisations covering both staff and wages employees in various locations. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I presume the honourable senator is referring to the Standards for the Technical Equipment and Operation of Television Stations. These standards, which reflect international standards and practices, are intended to ensure that the radiated signal of a television station is of sufficient quality to provide for satisfactory operation of television receivers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are manually assisted trunk calls, where an additional charge is made because the caller had the opportunity of using STD but chose to use an operator, dearer than STD due to the following factors in the tariff structure:
(a) the calls are charged in multiples of three minutes, so that a minute called is charged as for three, and a four minute call as for six;
(b) there is a surcharge, currently 70c, on each such call; and

(c) during the period when STD calls are subject to a discount, manually assisted calls are still charged the full rate, so that a one hour call from Canberra to Adelaide, after 9 p.m., costs $21.60 by STD but $54.70 via the operator, an effective total surcharge of $33.10.
(2) What is the estimated annual additional revenue from assisted trunk calls, as compared to the revenue from STD calls of the same actual duration, resulting from each of the above three factors.
(3) What is the justification for making these additional charges.
(4) What alternative to manually assisted tariff structures have been considered.

(5) Has any consideration been given to a tariff structure in which the charge for the manually connected call is as near as practicable to the cost of the equivalent STD call, with the addition of a tapered surcharge, not exceeding, say 50 per cent of the time charge, with the surcharge being subject to a maximum so set that the total revenue from surcharges would pay for the extra costs incurred in handling the manually assisted calls.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, it is unusual for calls to be as extensive as the example given in (c). Telecom Australia advised that studies conducted in 1979 showed that the average duration of a manually connected trunk call is 5.1 minutes in which case the price differential is much lower.

(2) There were about 54 million operator assisted telephone trunk calls connected in 1979-80 and the total earnings from these calls amounted to approximately $134m. However, it would not be possible to indicate the order of revenue that could have been received for the calls if STD rates had applied, without an exhaustive study of telephone trunk call dockets.

(3) Telephone trunk calls booked with an exchange operator cost far more to handle than those dialled automatically by a subscriber. A recent study showed that, on average, additional costs in excess of $2.50 a call were incurred when connection by an operator was involved. Penalty rates are also payable to operating staff handling these calls in the evening and at weekends.
(4) and (5) Telecom has advised that there are a variety of alternative tariff structures which have been or could be considered.

In regard to the suggestion that a manually connected call be charged as near as practicable to the cost of the equivalent STD call, Telecom is of the opinion that, if telephonists were required to time and charge on an elapsed time basis, its operating costs would inevitably increase further because a greater degree of supervision of calls would be required and telephonists would take longer to work out the cost of such calls because of the varying charging arrangements that would apply. These factors, in turn, would reduce the number of calls that could be handled in a given period of time. In regard to the suggestion of a 50 per cent surcharge, the present fee of 70 cents is designed primarily to offset, to some extent, the labour costs involved in effecting the connection of the call. These costs do not vary to any appreciable extent with distance. Under the approach suggested the shorter distance calls would attract a relatively low operator surcharge whilst those made over the larger distances would attract a high fee which would be difficult to justify on the grounds of costs incurred.
Overall, Telecom considers that the existing charging arrangements most appropriately reflect the factors involved, i.e. duration, distance and the costs of handling a particular call.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: How many Aboriginal-
(a) people;
(b) men;
(c) women;
(d) people in the 15 to 19 age group;
(e) and people in the 20 to 25 age group, are currently in receipt of unemployment benefit in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) to (e) There is no provision on Department of Social Security claim forms to identify whether an applicant is an Aboriginal. The Department does not, therefore, maintain regular statistics on the number of Aboriginals in receipt of unemployment benefit.

Certain information on Aboriginals in receipt of unemployment benefit is obtained at the time of each Quarterly Survey of Unemployment Benefit Recipients conducted by my Department. The information on whether or not an unemployment beneficiary is an Aboriginal is based on an identification system adopted by the Commonwealth Employment Service at the time of registration for work. However, statistics on Aboriginals in receipt of unemployment benefit have not been published for the last 3 years in the Report of the Quarterly Survey of Unemployment beneficiaries due to doubts about the reliability of these figures.
The possibility of collecting statistics on Aboriginals in receipt of social security payments by means of an additional question on application forms is currently under examination.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

(4) How many Aboriginal people live in these communities.
(5) How many Aboriginal communities through Australia have access to two way radio.
(6) How many Aboriginal people live in those communities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is research being done overseas into the use of water hyacinth as a feed source for the preparation of an alternative transport fuel.

(2) What research is being undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation into the use of water hyacinth in Australia for similar purposes, given the ample supply of water hyacinth in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes-Research has been undertaken on a laboratory scale in the US on the conversion of water hyacinth to methane which can be used as a transport fuel. Research by the US National Aeronautical and Space Administration (NASA) indicated yields of about 14 cubic metres of methane (equivalent to 9 litres of petrol) per tonne of water hyacinth which contains 93 per cent to 96 per cent water.

(2) CSIRO is not undertaking research on the use of water hyacinth for fuel production. Results from the only relevant study in Australia of which CSIRO is aware, suggests that some 30 to 50 tonnes/hectare of dry matter per year could be obtained from water hyacinth growing in the Fitzroy River in Queensland. From 2000 ha, the estimated harvestable area of infestation in the Fitzroy in 1973, the equivalent of only about 0.1 per cent of the petrol used in Australia in 1977-78 could theoretically be produced.

This information suggests that the area of water in Australia capable of producing recoverable water hyacinth is inadequate to support the production of alternative fuel on an economically attractive basis at the present time. Associated technical problems could further reduce the viability of such an undertaking.
